{{pp|small=yes}} {{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{For|the bodybuilder of the same name|Jay Cutler (bodybuilder)}} {{Infobox NFL biography |name=Jay Cutler |image=Jay cutler 2015.jpg |image_size=240 |alt= |caption= Cutler with the Chicago Bears in 2015 |position=[[Quarterback]] |number = 6 |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1983|4|29|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Santa Claus, Indiana]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 3 |weight_lbs = 231 |college=[[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]] |high_school = [[Heritage Hills High School|Lincoln City (IN) Heritage Hills]] |draftyear=2006 |draftround=1 |draftpick=11 |pastteams= * [[Denver Broncos]] ({{NFL Year|2006}}–{{NFL Year|2008}}) * [[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2009}}–{{NFL Year|2016}}) * [[Miami Dolphins]] ({{NFL Year|2017}}) |status= |highlights= * [[Pro Bowl]] ([[2009 Pro Bowl|2008]]) *First-team All-[[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] ([[2005 All-SEC football team|2005]]) |statlabel1=Passing attempts |statvalue1=4,920 |statlabel2=Passing completions |statvalue2=3,048 |statlabel3=Percentage |statvalue3=62.0 |statlabel4=Passing yards |statvalue4=35,133 |statlabel5=[[Touchdown|TD]]–[[Interception|INT]] |statvalue5=227–160 |statlabel6=[[Passer rating]] |statvalue6=85.3 |nfl=CUT288111 }} '''Jay Christopher Cutler''' (born April 29, 1983) is a former [[American football]] [[quarterback]] who played 12 seasons in the [[National Football League]]. He played [[college football]] at [[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]] and was drafted by the [[Denver Broncos]] in the first round of the [[2006 NFL Draft]], for whom he played for three seasons. In 2009, he was traded to the [[Chicago Bears]], where he played for eight seasons.
Following the [[2016 NFL season|2016 season]], Cutler announced his retirement and his intention to become a [[sportscaster]] for [[NFL on Fox]]'s television broadcasts. However, following a season-ending injury to [[Miami Dolphins]] quarterback [[Ryan Tannehill]] in August 2017, Cutler came out of retirement and signed a one-year deal with the team. {{TOClimit|limit=3}}
==Early years== Jay Cutler was born in [[Santa Claus, Indiana]], in 1983. Cutler attended [[Heritage Hills High School]] in [[Lincoln City, Indiana]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/espn/columns/story?columnist=forde_pat&id=2415795 |title=Christmas in April for Cutler |last=Forde |first=Pat |date=2006-04-20 |work=ESPN |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> He [[Starting lineup|started]] three years at quarterback for the Patriots football team, amassing a combined 26–1 record in his junior and senior years, including a perfect 15–0 during his senior year. Cutler and his team outscored opponents 746–85, including a 90–0 shutout at [[Pike Central High School|Pike Central]]. During his senior year, Cutler connected on 122 of 202 passes (60.4%) for 2,252 yards with 31 [[touchdown]]s, while rushing 65 times for 493 yards with 11 touchdowns.<ref name=broncossitebio>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/page.php?id=498&contentID=5907 |title=– Official Website Of The Denver Broncos |publisher=Denverbroncos.com |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703051721/http://www.denverbroncos.com/page.php?id=498&contentID=5907|archivedate=July 3, 2007}}</ref> He also started at [[Safety (American football position)|safety]] for three years, [[Interception|intercepting]] nine passes as a senior, 12th overall in the state.<ref name=broncossitebio /> His team's perfect record during his senior year included the school's first 3A state championship, where Heritage Hills beat [[Zionsville, Indiana|Zionsville]] in [[Overtime (sports)|overtime]], 27–24. The most notable play of the game occurred when Cutler [[Lateral pass|lateraled]] the ball to the [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]], Cole Seifrig, who then passed it to Cutler who ran it into the [[end zone]].<ref name="2000 IHSAA finals">{{cite web |url=http://www.ihsaa.org/b-football/00Class3AFinals.htm |title=2000 Indiana high school finals |publisher=IHSAA |accessdate=December 11, 2006}}</ref> Cutler also played strong safety in the state championship and made 19 tackles.<ref>{{cite web|title=IHSAA State Box|url=http://www.ihsaa.org/Portals/0/boys%20sports/boys%20football/Box%20Scores/2000013ABoxScore.pdf|accessdate=6 February 2014}}</ref>
Cutler was named a first-team All-State selection by the [[Associated Press]] as a senior.<ref name=broncossitebio /> In addition to playing [[American football|football]] in high school, he was a first-team all-state selection in [[basketball]] and garnered honorable mention all-state accolades as a [[shortstop]] in [[baseball]].<ref name=broncossitebio />
Cutler grew up as a [[Chicago Bears]] fan during his youth in Indiana.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/columns/story?columnist=drehs_wayne&id=4192431 |title=Wayne Drehs: Chicago Bears quarterback Jay Cutler is feeling the love – ESPN Chicago |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref>
==College career== Cutler attended [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/jay-cutler-1.html |title=Jay Cutler College Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> He started all 45 career games that he played for the [[Vanderbilt Commodores football]] team, the most starts by a quarterback in school history. He did not miss a game in college due to [[injury]].<ref name=broncossitebio /> The Commodores were 11–35 during his [[tenure]], including going 5–27 versus the SEC.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/vanderbilt/ |title=Vanderbilt Commodores Football Record By Year |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> In 2002, Cutler set the [[Vanderbilt Commodores football statistical leaders|school record]] for touchdowns and rushing yards by a freshman and rushed for more yards than any other [[Southeastern Conference]] quarterback that year. The Associated Press honored him with a first-team freshman All-SEC selection.<ref name=broncossitebio /> In 2004, as a junior, Cutler completed 61.0 percent of his passes, setting a school record, while throwing for 1,844 yards with 10 touchdowns and a career-low five interceptions.<ref name=broncossitebio /> [[Image:2004 Vanderbilt-Navy Game QB Jay Cutler.jpg|thumb|240px|left|Cutler being [[Quarterback sack|sacked]] by [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]] [[linebacker]] Jeremy Chase]] The 2005 season, Cutler's final year of play at Vanderbilt, was his most successful. As an 11-game starter, he completed 273 of 462 passes (59.1%) for 3,073 yards, 21 touchdowns and nine interceptions, as he became the first Commodore to win the SEC Offensive Player of the Year (coaches and media) since 1967.<ref name=broncossitebio /><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/awards/sec-opoy.html |title=SEC Offensive Player of the Year Winners |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> With his senior-season performance, Cutler became the second Commodore to throw for more than 3,000 yards in a season, while his 273 completions and 21 touchdowns ranked second on the school’s single-season list.<ref name=broncossitebio /> He led the Commodores to victories over [[Wake Forest Demon Deacons football|Wake Forest]], [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]], [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]], [[University of Richmond|Richmond]] and [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2005-09-01-wake-forest.html |title=Vanderbilt at Wake Forest Box Score, September 1, 2005 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2005-09-10-arkansas.html |title=Vanderbilt at Arkansas Box Score, September 10, 2005 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2005-09-17-vanderbilt.html |title=Ole Miss at Vanderbilt Box Score, September 17, 2005 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2005-11-19-tennessee.html |title=Vanderbilt at Tennessee Box Score, November 19, 2005 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> The Commodores also scored the second most points ever (42) laid upon the [[Florida Gators football|Florida Gators]] at their current home field at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]]. Vanderbilt nearly upset the 13th-ranked Gators before falling 49–42 in the second overtime after a controversial excessive celebration call prevented the Commodores from going for 2 at the end of regulation.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2005-11-05-florida.html |title=Vanderbilt at Florida Box Score, November 5, 2005 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> Reflecting on Cutler's college career, former [[Denver Broncos]] safety [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] said, "If this guy can take a bunch of future doctors and lawyers and have them competing against the Florida Gators, this guy is a stud."<ref 'nyt_battista'>{{cite news |publisher=New York Times |date=December 31, 2006 |accessdate=December 31, 2006 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/31/sports/football/31broncos.html?_r=1&oref=slogin |title=With Eye on Playoffs, Broncos Turn to Cutler |author=Judy Battista}}</ref>
Cutler ended his career by leading Vanderbilt past [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] 28–24, their first over the Volunteers since 1982 (the year before Cutler was born), and the first in [[Knoxville]] since 1975.<ref name="VandySports">{{cite web |url=http://vanderbilt.rivals.com/content.asp?SID=1087&CID=300031 |title=Football History |publisher=VandySports.com ([[Rivals.com]] network) |accessdate=November 26, 2006}}</ref> Cutler passed for three touchdowns and 315 yards, becoming the first quarterback in school history to record four consecutive 300-yard passing performances.<ref name=broncossitebio /> Cutler's final play in college was the game-winning (and streak-ending) touchdown pass to teammate [[Earl Bennett]] against Tennessee. A finalist for the [[Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award]] (nation’s top senior quarterback), Cutler was a first-team All-SEC pick by the league’s coaches and led the conference with a [[Vanderbilt Commodores football statistical leaders#Total offense|school-record]] 3,288 yards of total offense.<ref name=broncossitebio /><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/conferences/sec/2005-leaders.html |title=2005 Southeastern Conference Leaders |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref>
While at Vanderbilt, Cutler was a three-year [[Captain (sports)|captain]] and four-year starter, setting [[Vanderbilt Commodores football statistical leaders|school career records]] for total offense (9,953 yards), touchdown passes (59), passing yards (8,697), pass completions (710), pass attempts (1,242), and combined touchdowns (76).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/vanderbilt/passing.html |title=Vanderbilt Commodores Passing |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
Cutler graduated from Vanderbilt in 2005 with a [[bachelor]]'s degree in human and organizational development.<ref name=broncossitebio />
===Awards and honors=== * ''[[The Sporting News]]'' third-team freshman [[All-America]]n (2002) * [[Associated Press]] first-team freshman All-[[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] (2002) * First-team All-SEC (2005) * SEC Offensive Player of the Year (2005)''' *[[Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award]] finalist (2005) *[[Maxwell Award]] Semifinalist (2005) *[[Davey O'Brien Award]] Finalist (2005) *[[Manning Award]] Finalist (2005) *[[Sammy Baugh Trophy]] Finalist (2005)
===Records=== Vanderbilt University [[Vanderbilt Commodores football statistical leaders|school career records]]: * ''Total offense'': 9,953 * ''Touchdown passes'': 59 * ''Passing yards'': 8,697 * ''Pass completions'': 710 * ''Pass attempts'': 1,242 * ''Combined touchdowns'': 76

Career ! 710!! 1242!!57.2 !! 8,697 !! 7.0 !! 59!! 36 !!80 !! 125.9 !! 453!!1256!!2.8 !!17 |}
==Professional career== {{NFL predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 3¼ | weight = 226 | dash = 4.77 | ten split = 1.61 | twenty split = 2.79 | shuttle = 4.31 | cone drill = 7.12 | vertical = | broad ft = | broad in = | bench = 23 | wonderlic = 26 | note = All values from the [[NFL Combine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=17518&draftyear=2006&genpos=qb |title=Jay Cutler 2006 NFL Draft Scout Player Profile |publisher=Nfldraftscout.com |date=September 21, 2006 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref><ref name="packers2006">[http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2006/04/27/1/ Packers.com, April 27, 2006: Gil Brandt's Analysis By Position: Quarterbacks] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012204351/http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2006/04/27/1/ |date=October 12, 2007 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.macmirabile.com/Wonderlic.htm NFL Quarterback Wonderlic Scores] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109092359/http://www.macmirabile.com/Wonderlic.htm |date=January 9, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nflcombineresults.com/playerpage.php?f=Jay&l=Cutler&i=7345 |title=Jay Cutler - QB - Vanderbilt - 2006 NFL Combine Results |publisher=NFL Combine Results |accessdate=September 8, 2012}}</ref> }}
Cutler was ranked by many experts as the third-best quarterback prospect in the [[2006 NFL Draft]], after [[Matt Leinart]] of [[University of Southern California|USC]] and [[Vince Young]] of [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]]. [[ESPN]]'s [[Chris Mortensen]] and [[Ron Jaworski]] tabbed him as the best quarterback available in the draft, and some [[Scout (sport)|scouts]] believed he had better arm strength than Young and Leinart, and compared him to [[Brett Favre]] for his [[gunslinger]] attitude.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=sando_mike&id=3084020 |title=ESPN – To win big, Broncos must add to Cutler supporting cast – NFL |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=October 28, 2007 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Wyatt |first=Jim |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/draft/2006-02-28-cutler-stock_x.htm |title=Cutler's stock continues to skyrocket |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=February 28, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> At the 2006 [[NFL Scouting Combine]], Cutler completed 23 repetitions of a 225-pound [[bench press]] (more than some linemen) and ran a [[40-yard dash]] in 4.77 seconds.<ref name="packers2006" />
Cutler was selected by the [[Denver Broncos]] in the first round with the 11th pick in the draft, acquired from the [[St. Louis Rams]] for their 1st and 3rd round picks.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2006/draft.htm |title=2006 NFL Draft Listing |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Many believed Cutler was chosen by the Broncos due to the lackluster performance in the previous season's [[NFL playoffs, 2005-06#AFC: Pittsburgh Steelers 34, Denver Broncos 17|AFC Championship Game]] of [[Jake Plummer]].<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12568906/ |title=Opinion: Broncos put Plummer in tough predicament - NFL - MSNBC.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=May 1, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> After the pick by Denver, Cutler said, "We had no warning. I think I knew about 15 seconds before everyone else did."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/football/nfl/specials/draft/2006/04/29/bc.fbn.broncosdraft.ap/ |title=SI.com – 2006 NFL Draft – Broncos move up in draft to pick quarterback – Saturday April 29, 2006 4:00PM |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=April 29, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Cutler, as predicted by most, was the third quarterback chosen, after Young (3rd overall) and Leinart (10th). He is the third first-round pick to come from Vanderbilt, preceded by [[Will Wolford]] and [[Bill Wade]]. On July 27, 2006, Cutler agreed to terms on a six-year $48 million contract, which included $11 million in bonuses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2532044 |title=ESPN – QB Cutler agrees to six-year deal with Broncos – NFL |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=July 28, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref>
===Denver Broncos===
====2006 season==== After a strong training camp in 2006, Cutler was promoted from third to second on the Broncos' quarterback [[depth chart]] ahead of [[Bradlee Van Pelt]]. He passed for more yards than any other rookie in the preseason.
On November 27, head coach [[Mike Shanahan]] officially announced that Cutler would replace [[Jake Plummer]] as starting quarterback despite a 7-4 record because, "I think he gives us the best chance to win now."<ref name="Post_official"> {{cite news |url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_4729429 |date=November 27, 2006 |accessdate=November 27, 2006 |publisher=[[Denver Post]] |author=Denver Post Staff |title=Cutler's promotion official}}</ref><ref name="Broncos_starter">{{cite web |url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/page.php?id=334&storyID=6292 |title=Cutler to Start |author=Andrew Mason |publisher=[[Denver Broncos]] |date=November 27, 2006 |accessdate=November 27, 2006}}</ref> The controversial decision capped weeks of speculation and rumors about Cutler's impending promotion to a starting role.<ref name="Tennesseean_Shan">{{cite web |publisher=[[The Tennessean]] |accessdate=November 4, 2006 |date=October 27, 2006 |url=http://www.tennessean.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061027/SPORTS11/610270421/0/SPORTS01 |title=False start: Shanahan rips Cutler debut report |author=Mike Organ}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010}}</ref>
Cutler took his first NFL snap on December 3 (Week 13), and after some initial jitters (0-3 with sack and fumble) completed his first touchdown to [[tight end]] [[Stephen Alexander (American football)|Stephen Alexander]] in the second quarter.<ref>{{cite web|author=Invesco Field, Denver, CO  |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=261203007 |title=ESPN – Hawks edge Broncos behind Brown's game-winning FG – NFL Football Recap |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 3, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> In the fourth quarter, he threw a memorable 71-yard touchdown to fellow-rookie [[Brandon Marshall]] to tie the game 20–20. It was one of the longest touchdown passes for a debut in NFL history and was also the second-longest pass play between two rookies in Broncos history.<ref name=broncossitebio /> He also had two interceptions and took three sacks in the loss.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200612030den.htm |title=Seattle Seahawks at Denver Broncos - December 3rd, 2006 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
On December 10, in a road loss against the [[2006 San Diego Chargers season|San Diego Chargers]], Cutler connected with tight end [[Tony Scheffler]] for two touchdowns in a span of 48 seconds, which is tied for fastest, in league history that two rookies produced a pair of scoring passes.<ref name=broncossitebio />
Cutler's first win came in his third start on December 17, which was a 37–20 road victory over the [[2006 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=261217022 |title=ESPN – Broncos' Cutler outduels Cards' Leinart in rookie battle – NFL Football Recap |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 17, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> He finished the game 21-of-31 with 261 yards, two touchdowns, an interception and a QB rating of 101.7, the highest for a Broncos rookie since [[John Elway]] in 1983.<ref name=broncossitebio /> One touchdown traveled 65 yards in the air, and was recorded as a 54-yard touchdown to [[Javon Walker]] on the Broncos' third play of the game. Shanahan said to the media, "You saw what he could do today. It doesn't take a genius out there to figure out this guy is very composed, can make all the throws and plays with a lot of confidence."<ref name="baum_2006_az">{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20061217022 |title=Denver 37, Arizona 20 |author=Bob Baum |publisher=Associated Press via [[Yahoo!]] Sports |date=December 15, 2006 |accessdate=December 15, 2006}}</ref>
Cutler then led the Broncos to a [[Christmas Eve]] win over the [[Cincinnati Bengals]], 24–23, in his fourth start on the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=261224007 |title=ESPN – Muffed extra point costs Bengals shot at clinching – NFL Football Recap |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 24, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> He went 12-of-23 with 179 yards, two touchdowns and one interception. He also directed the Broncos on a 99-yard drive in the third quarter that culminated on a [[Mike Bell (running back)|Mike Bell]] two-yard touchdown run. As a result of the two passing touchdowns in the game against the Bengals, Cutler became the first rookie QB in NFL history<ref>second player overall, joining the [[Washington Redskins]]' [[Mark Rypien]] in 1988</ref> to throw for at least two touchdowns in each of his first four games played.<ref name=broncossitebio /> He also became the second rookie in league history (fifth player overall) to throw at least two touchdown passes in each of his first four starts.<ref name=broncossitebio /><ref>The only other rookie to accomplish the feat was [[Dan Marino]] in his 1983 rookie season.</ref><ref name="rasizer_calm">{{cite news |url=http://www.insidedenver.com/drmn/nfl/article/0,2777,DRMN_23918_5237764,00.html |date=December 27, 2006 |accessdate=December 27, 2006 |title=Cutler's calm catching |author=Lee Rasizer |publisher=[[Rocky Mountain News]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010}}</ref>
The Broncos' quest to clinch a playoff berth came up short in the final game of the season, when they fell at home 26–23 in overtime to the [[San Francisco 49ers]]. The loss dropped the Broncos to a 9–7 overall record and 4–4 at home. Despite sustaining a concussion in the first half, Cutler finished 21 of 32 with 230 yards and a touchdown, and led Denver on a game-tying touchdown drive in the closing minutes of regulation to force overtime.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200612310den.htm |title=San Francisco 49ers at Denver Broncos - December 31st, 2006 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
In five games played on the season, Cutler finished with a record of 2–3, and went 81-of-137 for 1,001 yards, 9 touchdowns, and 5 interceptions, earning a franchise rookie record passer rating of 88.5.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jay Cutler  #6  QB |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/players/stats?playerId=9597 |title=ESPN – Jay Cutler Stats, News, Photos – Denver Broncos – NFL Football |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=April 29, 1983 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{As of|2017}}, this is the only Denver franchise record he still holds.</ref> He posted the second-highest touchdown percentage (6.6) and third-highest TD-to-INT ratio (1.8) among NFL rookies since 1970 with at least 125 passing attempts.<ref name=broncossitebio />
====2007 season==== [[Image:Jaycutler.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Cutler preparing for the [[Tennessee Titans|Titans]] in a 2007 MNF game.]] The [[2007 NFL season]] marked Cutler's first full season as the starting quarterback of the Denver Broncos. In the first game of the season against the [[Buffalo Bills]], Cutler led Denver to a comeback win on a 12-play, 42-yard drive culminating in a [[Jason Elam]] 42-yard [[Field goal (football)|field goal]] as time expired.<ref name=broncossitebio /> Cutler's pass attempts (39), completions (23), and yards (304) for the game were career-highs at the time.<ref name=broncossitebio /> He led Denver to their second straight comeback win the next week in the home opener against the Oakland Raiders. Late in regulation, Cutler moved the team 78 yards in 15 plays for the game-tying field goal with 2:18 remaining.<ref name=broncossitebio /> The game went into overtime, where he engineered a 52-yard drive that led to another game-winning field goal by Elam. Cutler had a touchdown pass during the game, making him the first Broncos passer to begin his Broncos career with at least one touchdown pass in his first seven starts.<ref name=broncossitebio /> The streak reached nine games through losses to [[Jacksonville Jaguars|Jacksonville]] and at [[Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis]] (which featured his first career rushing touchdown), but ended with a 41–3 home loss to the San Diego Chargers in the fifth game of the season.<ref name=broncossitebio />
After the [[Bye (sports)|bye week]] in Week 6, the 2-3 Broncos beat the 4–1 [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], 31–28 (all three wins on last-second Elam field goals). Cutler had a [[Passer rating|QB rating]] of 106.7, and career highs of 75.9% passes completed, three touchdowns, 41 rushing yards and a long run of 31 yards, earning [[NBC Sunday Night Football]]'s Horse Trailer Player of the Game (with Elam).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200710210den.htm |title=Pittsburgh Steelers at Denver Broncos - October 21st, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref name=broncossitebio /> Cutler finally had an interception-free game in his 12th start against the 6–1 [[Green Bay Packers]], in which he drove 89-yards for a game-tying field goal in the last 2:27 of regulation, before losing in overtime, 19–13, on Green Bay's first play from scrimmage.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200710290den.htm |title=Green Bay Packers at Denver Broncos - October 29th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In week 8, Cutler had just four attempts against the [[Detroit Lions]] before leaving with a leg injury; backup [[Patrick Ramsey]] floundered in a 44–7 loss. Cutler returned the next week in a 27–11 victory at [[Kansas City Chiefs|Kansas City]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200711110kan.htm |title=Denver Broncos at Kansas City Chiefs - November 11th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
In Week 10, the 4-5 Broncos faced the 6-3 [[Tennessee Titans]] (and fellow 2006 draftee [[Vince Young]] for the first time) in a [[Monday Night Football|MNF Game]].<ref name="mnfbroncostitans">{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=271119007 |title=ESPN – Four TDs of 40-plus yards power Broncos – NFL Football Recap |publisher=Scores.espn.go.com |date=November 19, 2007 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Cutler posted a career-second-best 137.0 passer rating in a 34–20 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200711190den.htm |title=Tennessee Titans at Denver Broncos - November 19th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> He was the first Broncos quarterback since Elway in 1995 to throw two 40+ yard touchdowns in a game (of the team's franchise-record four 40+ yard touchdowns that night), and the 5–5 Broncos moved into a tie with [[San Diego Chargers|San Diego]] atop the [[AFC West]]. However, the Broncos won only one of the next five games, a 41–7 Chiefs blowout. In that game, Cutler passed for four touchdowns and a then-career-best rating of 141.0.<ref>{{cite web|author=Invesco Field, Denver, CO  |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=271209007 |title=ESPN – Cutler tosses career-high four TDs as Broncos crush Chiefs – NFL Football Recap |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 9, 2007 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> But that bright spot came between two pairs of losses; in the four games Cutler had five interceptions, took 12 sacks, twice had a rating under 50.0, and culminated in 23-3 loss to San Diego that eliminated the Broncos from the playoffs.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200712240sdg.htm |title=Denver Broncos at San Diego Chargers - December 24th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Cutler salvaged a 7-9 record with a 22-19 overtime win over [[Minnesota Vikings|Minnesota]], eliminating them as well.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200712300den.htm |title=Minnesota Vikings at Denver Broncos - December 30th, 2007 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
Denver missed the playoffs for a second straight year. Cutler started all 16 games, completing 297-of-467 passes (63.6%) for 3,497 yards, 20 touchdowns and 14 interceptions. He was the NFL’s 12th-ranked passer (88.1) and also had the tenth-most passing yards (3,497). Furthermore, Cutler was the league’s ninth-best third-down passer, with a 92.1 passer rating (73-of-125 for 901 yards, eight touchdowns, and three interceptions). It was the seventh most passing yards in Broncos history, and third-best completion percentage.<ref name=broncossitebio /> Like his predecessor [[Jake Plummer|Plummer]], Cutler showed mobility with 44 rushes for 205 yards (4.7 yards per carry) and a touchdown on the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fantasyfootball.usatoday.com/content/player.asp?id=3608&sport=NFL |title=Jay Cutler : USATODAY.com - Jay Cutler Biography from USATODAY.com |publisher=Fantasyfootball.usatoday.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120707053221/http://fantasyfootball.usatoday.com/content/player.asp?sport=NFL&id=3608 |archivedate=July 7, 2012 }}</ref>
In late 2007, various experts suggested Cutler was the young quarterback most likely to reach the elite status along the lines of [[Peyton Manning]] and [[Tom Brady]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=sando_mike&id=3142771 |title=ESPN – In young QB market, Cutler hot, Eli Manning not – NFL |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 13, 2007 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Cutler, [[Brandon Marshall]] and [[Tony Scheffler]] went to Atlanta together to train and work on timing for the [[2008 Denver Broncos season|2008 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=353844 |title=Real Insight. Real Fans. Real Conversations |publisher=Sporting News |date=August 15, 2012 |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090910070735/http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/article/2008-02-17/inside-dish-no-rest-broncos-trio |archivedate=September 10, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
====2008 season==== Before the [[2008 Denver Broncos season|2008 regular season]] began, Cutler and tight end [[Daniel Graham]] were voted [[National Football League team captains|offensive captains]] by Broncos teammates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/sep/05/broncos-select-team-captains/ |title=Broncos select team captains |publisher=Rockymountainnews.com |date=September 5, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref>
Cutler started the season with a 41-14 ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' victory over [[Oakland Raiders|Oakland]]. He completed 16-of-24 passes for 300 yards and two touchdowns,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=280908013 |title=Denver Broncos vs. Oakland Raiders – Recap – September 08, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=September 8, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=The Denver Post |url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_10431872 |title=Marshall roots on his teammates in rout of Raiders |publisher=The Denver Post |date=September 14, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> and had the league's second-highest passer rating (137.5).<ref name="nfl-pass-2008">{{cite web|title=NFL Passing Stats: 2008|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=September 11, 2008|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/statistics?stat=pass&season=2&year=2008}}</ref> The next week, Cutler and the Broncos defeated the [[San Diego Chargers]] in Denver, 39–38.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=280914007 |title=San Diego Chargers vs. Denver Broncos – Recap – September 14, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Scores.espn.go.com |date=September 14, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Cutler went 36-of-50, with 350 yards passing and a career-best-tying four touchdowns, including one to [[Eddie Royal]] on 4th and Goal with 0:24 left, followed by a game-winning two-point conversion again to Royal. This occurred one play after Cutler fumbled, but an inadvertent whistle by referee [[Ed Hochuli]] before the Chargers recovered gave the Broncos the ball back.<ref>{{cite news |title=NFL will lower Ed Hochuli's grade after blown call |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2008-09-15-hochuli_N.htm |agency=Associated Press |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=December 13, 2008 | work=USA Today}}</ref> In Week 3, Cutler had 264 yards and two touchdowns in a 34-22 home win over [[New Orleans Saints|New Orleans]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200809210den.htm |title=New Orleans Saints at Denver Broncos - September 21st, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Cutler threw two interceptions for the first time in the Broncos first defeat, 33–19 at [[Kansas City Chiefs|Kansas City]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200809280kan.htm |title=Denver Broncos at Kansas City Chiefs - September 28th, 2008 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Despite this, he finished September first in the AFC in completions (102), passing yards (1,275), and attempts (157), second in yards per attempt (8.12), third in passing touchdowns (9) and quarterback rating (98.6), and fifth in completion percentage (65.0%), winning [[American Football Conference|AFC]] Offensive Player of the Month honors for the first time in his career.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cbs4denver.com/broncos/broncos.chiefs.kansas.2.830488.html |title=Cutler Named AFC Offensive Player Of The Month |publisher=Cbs4denver.com |date=October 1, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205043012/http://cbs4denver.com/broncos/broncos.chiefs.kansas.2.830488.html |archivedate=December 5, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:JayCutlergfdl (cropped).JPG|thumb|left|upright|Cutler with the Denver Broncos in 2008]] The Broncos edged [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay]] 16–13 behind Cutler's 23-of-34 performance with 227 yards, one touchdown and no interceptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281005007 |title=Tampa Bay Buccaneers vs. Denver Broncos – Recap – October 05, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=October 5, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> The Broncos were 4–1 and leading [[American Football Conference West Division|AFC West]]. But then followed a 24-7 loss to [[Jacksonville Jaguars]], where Cutler passed for just 192 yards, two touchdowns and one interception.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281012007 |title=Jacksonville Jaguars vs. Denver Broncos – Recap – October 12, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=October 12, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Next, Cutler injured his [[index finger]] on the first play of a 41-7 drubbing at [[New England Patriots|New England]]; he ended the night with 168 yards and two interceptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281020017 |title=Denver Broncos vs. New England Patriots – Recap – October 20, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=October 20, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> After a [[Bye (sports)|bye week]], the Broncos suffered their third straight defeat, 26-17 to [[Miami Dolphins|Miami]], behind Cutler's 24-of-46 passing for 307 yards, two touchdowns and season-high three interceptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281102007 |title=Miami Dolphins vs. Denver Broncos – Recap – November 02, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=November 2, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> During the 1-4 skid, Cutler had all seven of the Broncos touchdowns.
In game 9, the Broncos found themselves down 23-10 at [[Cleveland Browns|Cleveland]], but in the 4th quarter Cutler threw a career-long 93-yard touchdown to [[Eddie Royal]],<ref>{{As of|2017}}, it was also the 4th longest touchdown pass in Broncos history. See [https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/ptd_finder.cgi?request=1&match=play&year_min=1920&year_max=2016&team_id=den&game_type=R&game_num_min=0&game_num_max=99&week_num_min=0&week_num_max=99&td_type=pass&group_by_pass=qb&distance_min=80&distance_max=100&quarter=1&quarter=2&quarter=3&quarter=4&quarter=5&scorer_age_min=0&scorer_age_max=0&passer_age_min=0&passer_age_max=0&order_by=game_date List of 80+ Yard Broncos Touchdown Passes]</ref> followed by a touchdown passes to [[Daniel Graham]] and the game-winner to [[Brandon Marshall]] with 1:14 left.<ref name=2008broncosbrowns>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281106005 |title=Denver Broncos vs. Cleveland Browns – Recap – November 06, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=November 6, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29658&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2008&week=REG10 |title=Broncos do what they usually do vs. Browns – rally for late victory |publisher=Nfl.com |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Cutler finished the game going 24-of-42 with 447 yards (career-high), three touchdowns and one interception,<ref name=2008broncosbrowns /> and received AFC Offensive Player of the Week honors for the first time in his career.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_10958136 |title=Denver Broncos' Cutler named AFC player of week |publisher=Denverpost.com |date= November 11, 2008|accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> The next week, Cutler threw another late 4th quarter touchdown to [[Daniel Graham]] for a 24-20 win at [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281116001 |title=Injury-hit Broncos break out tricks to defeat Falcons |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=November 16, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref>
In game 11, Cutler's streak of games with a touchdown ended at 11 as he went 16-of-37 for 204 yards and an interception in a 31-10 loss to [[Oakland Raiders|Oakland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281123007 |title=Oakland Raiders vs. Denver Broncos – Recap – November 23, 2008 – ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=November 23, 2008 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> He did, however, reach 3,000 yards on the season, tying [[John Elway]] by reaching this mark in 11 games. In a windy game 12 at the [[New York Jets]], Cutler went 27-of-43 with 357 yards, two touchdowns and one interception in the 34–17 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281130020 |title=Denver Broncos vs. New York Jets - Recap - November 30, 2008 - ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=November 30, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> The 7-5 Broncos had a 3-game road win streak, 3 game home loss streak, and 3 game lead on [[San Diego Chargers|San Diego]] (who had their own 3 game loss streak) with four games remaining.
Cutler began December completing a season high 80% of his 40 passes for 286 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in a 24-17 win over the [[Kansas City|Chiefs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281207007 |title=Broncos get it together in 4th, put end to three-game home skid |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 7, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> The win came via a 95-yard drive and go-ahead touchdown pass to [[Brandon Marshall]] for Cutler's fourth rally of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29730&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2008&week=REG14 |title=Cutler leads Broncos to rare home win, closer to AFC West title |publisher=Nfl.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> However, Cutler was just 21-of-33 with 172 yards, one touchdown, and one interception in a 20-30 loss at Carolina,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281214029 |title=Smith, Williams power Panthers to perfect home record |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 14, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> and despite 359 yards and 2 rushing touchdowns, had no passing touchdowns and one interception in a 30-23 loss to [[Buffalo Bills|Buffalo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281221007 |title=Bills force Broncos to continue fight for playoff spot next week |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 21, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=The Denver Postdenverpost.com |url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_11285737 |title=QB Cutler sets records, but one big goal remains |publisher=Denverpost.com |date= December 22, 2008|accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> This set up a winner-takes-the-division season finale against the [[San Diego Chargers]]. Cutler went 33-of-49 with 316 yards, one touchdown, and two interceptions, but it wasn't enough to counteract the Chargers seven touchdowns and Denver lost 52–21, failing to reach the playoffs for the third straight season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=281228024 |title=Rivers, Chargers (8–8) win West crown in rout |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=December 28, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
Cutler finished the season with career-highs in passing completions (384), passing attempts (616), passing yards (4,526), passing touchdowns (25), interceptions (18), rushing attempts (57) and rushing touchdowns (2).<ref>{{cite web|author=Jay Cutler   |url=http://www.nfl.com/players/profile?id=CUT288111 |title=Jay Cutler, QB for the Chicago Bears at |publisher=Nfl.com |date=November 20, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> At the time, his passing yards, completions and attempts were all single-season franchise records for the Broncos. He also had the most 300-yard passing games (8) in team history.<ref name=broncossitebio /><ref>All since eclipsed.</ref> For the season, Cutler ranked third in the NFL in completions (first in the AFC), second in passing attempts (first in the AFC), third in passing yards (first in the AFC) and seventh in passing touchdowns (third in the AFC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/stats/categorystats?season=2008&seasonType=REG&d-447263-o=2&conference=null&tabSeq=0&statisticCategory=PASSING&d-447263-p=1&d-447263-s=PASSING_COMPLETIONS&d-447263-n=1 |title=2008 NFL passing statistics |publisher=Nfl.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> He was selected as the [[FedEx Air & Ground NFL Players of the Week|FedEx Air Player of the Week]] for his performances during Weeks 10, 13 and 14. He finished third in fan voting for AFC quarterbacks in the [[2009 Pro Bowl]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcsouth/0-7-85/Final-fan-voting-for-Pro-Bowl.html |title=Final fan voting for Pro Bowl |publisher=Myespn.go.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208225502/http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcsouth/0-7-85/Final-fan-voting-for-Pro-Bowl.html |archivedate=February 8, 2009 |df= }}</ref> and was officially selected as a reserve.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_11245970 |title=Broncos: Marshall, Cutler to Pro Bowl |publisher=Denverpost.com |date=September 14, 2010 |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |first=Mike |last=Klis}}</ref> Before the game in Hawaii, fellow Pro Bowlers [[Peyton Manning]], [[Nick Mangold]], and [[Kris Dielman]] threw him into a pool, ruining his [[blood sugar]] monitor. A replacement one was found at a drugstore, and Cutler played without incident.<ref name="Peyton's Pro Bowl Prank Goes Wrong">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/blog/the_sporting_blog/entry/view/17073/peytons_pro_bowl_prank_goes_wrong|title=Peyton's Pro Bowl Prank Goes Wrong|date=February 5, 2009|accessdate=March 1, 2009}}</ref>
===Chicago Bears===
====2009 season==== [[Image:Jay Cutler Training Camp.jpg|thumb|240px|left|Cutler points out the mike linebacker during training camp, 2009]] After the 2008 season, coach Shanahan was fired and replaced by the [[New England Patriots|Patriots]]' offensive coordinator [[Josh McDaniels]]. On February 28, 2009, ESPN reported that the Broncos were listening to trade offers for Cutler, a possibility he found upsetting.<ref>{{cite web |title=Source: Spurned Cutler wants to be traded |url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcwest/0-3-1666/Spurned-Cutler-wants-to-be-traded.html |last=Williamson |first=Bill |publisher=ESPN.com |date=February 28, 2009 |accessdate=March 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302053103/http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcwest/0-3-1666/Spurned-Cutler-wants-to-be-traded.html |archivedate=March 2, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Broncos">{{cite web |title=Cutler upset over potential deals to Detroit, Tampa Bay |url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/02/28/cutler-upset-over-potential-deals-to-detroit-tampa-bay/ |last=Schefter |first=Adam |publisher=NFL.com |date=February 28, 2009 |accessdate=February 28, 2009}}</ref> McDaniels denied interest in trades,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/03/03/mcdaniels-cutler-is-not-going-to-be-traded-period/ |title=NFL.com Blogs " Blog Archive McDaniels: Cutler will not be traded by Broncos " |publisher=Blogs.nfl.com |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> but Cutler did not believe him.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/broncos/ci_11882256 | work=Denver Post | first=Mike | last=Klis | title=Broncos' talk with Cutler sours | date=March 10, 2009}}</ref> On March 15, Cutler listed his [[Colorado]] home for sale,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3981792 |title=Denver Broncos quarterback Jay Cutler, parents selling Denver-area houses - ESPN |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=2009-03-15 |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref> and confirmed that he had officially asked the Broncos to trade him.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3983805 Jay Cutler Asks Broncos to Trade Him] ESPN, March 15, 2009</ref> On March 31, Broncos owner [[Pat Bowlen]] announced that the team would accommodate his request,<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090401/ap_on_sp_fo_ne/fbn_broncos_cutler_rift;_ylt=AkcuVH9ZEM8QdDTcVKcS3y3IyLQF Broncs Will Try to Trade Cutler] Yahoo Sports, March 31, 2009</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/03/31/bowlen-says-broncos-will-try-to-trade-cutler/ |title=Bowlen says Broncos will try to trade Cutler |publisher=Blogs.nfl.com |date=March 31, 2009 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> and three days later Cutler was indeed traded with the Broncos' 2009 fifth-round draft pick to the [[Chicago Bears]] for quarterback [[Kyle Orton]], the Bears' first- and third-round selections in 2009, and first-round pick in [[2010 NFL Draft|2010]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80f93745&template=with-video&confirm=true|title=New home Chicago: Broncos ship disgruntled QB Cutler to Bears|accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> On October 20, Cutler and the Bears came to terms on a two-year contract extension worth $30 million, running through 2013.<ref>{{cite news| title=Bears, Cutler agree on extension | date=October 20, 2009 | publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]] | url =https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=ApGvx6wT6Hi5myYNhWH1vuNDubYF?slug=ap-bears-cutlerextension&prov=ap&type=lgns | agency =Associated Press | accessdate =October 21, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Jay Cutler vs 49ers.jpg|thumb|right|Cutler passes in a game against the [[San Francisco 49ers]]]] Cutler was the subject of most of the praise and criticism during the Chicago Bears' mercurial season. He began the season with 4 INTs in a loss to [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]], followed by seven touchdowns to one interception in three straight wins with a 100+ QB Rating.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200909130gnb.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Green Bay Packers - September 13th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The Bears lost eight of the next ten games behind Cutler's 11 touchdowns vs NFL-leading 20 interceptions. This included a Game 9 loss to [[San Francisco 49ers|San Francisco]] where Cutler threw a career-high five interceptions and no touchdowns, and Game 14 loss at [[Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore]] where Cutler had career-worsts of 94 yards<ref>min. 15 attempts</ref> and a passer rating of 7.9.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200911120sfo.htm |title=Chicago Bears at San Francisco 49ers - November 12th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200912200rav.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Baltimore Ravens - December 20th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> But Cutler again reversed direction in Game 15 against [[Brett Favre]]'s division rival [[Minnesota Vikings|Vikings]], where he threw four touchdowns, including a go-ahead late in the 4th quarter, and 31-yard game-winner in overtime.<ref>{{cite web|title=Minnesota Vikings at Chicago Bears - December 28th, 2009|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200912280chi.htm|website=Pro-Football-Reference.com|language=en}}</ref> He earned Offensive Player of the Week for his effort against the Vikings.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2009/week_16.htm |title=2009 NFL Week 16 Leaders & Scores |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> He then ended the season with another four-touchdown outing and win over [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]]. Cutler finished the season with 27 touchdowns, league-leading 26 interceptions, 3,666 yards passing, and career-worst<ref>{{As of|2017}}</ref> passer rating of 76.8.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/stats/categorystats?archive=false&seasonType=REG&d-447263-o=2&conference=null&statisticCategory=PASSING&d-447263-s=PASSING_INTERCEPTIONS&experience=null&d-447263-n=1&season=2009&qualified=true&Submit=Go&tabSeq=0&d-447263-p=1 |title=NFL Stats by Category: Interceptions, descending |publisher=Nfl.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105085446/http://www.nfl.com/stats/categorystats?archive=false&seasonType=REG&d-447263-o=2&conference=null&statisticCategory=PASSING&d-447263-s=PASSING_INTERCEPTIONS&experience=null&d-447263-n=1&season=2009&qualified=true&Submit=Go&tabSeq=0&d-447263-p=1 |archivedate=November 5, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
====2010 season==== The Bears hired [[Mike Martz]] (famed for developing the [[St. Louis Rams]]' "[[Greatest Show on Turf]]") as offensive coordinator. Though Martz had been critical of Cutler as an analyst, both professed excitement about working together.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/news/story?id=4877772 |title=Chicago Bears hire Mike Martz as offensive coordinator - ESPN Chicago |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=February 2, 2010 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
Cutler led the Bears to a 3–0 start, throwing six touchdowns and only two interceptions. However, in week 4, Cutler was sacked nine times in the first half against the [[New York Giants]], missing the rest of that game and the next with a concussion.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201010030nyg.htm |title=Chicago Bears at New York Giants - October 3rd, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> He returned to six sacks in a loss to [[Seattle Seahawks|Seattle]] and 4 interceptions in a loss to [[Washington Redskins|Washington]], leaving the Bears at 4–3 at their [[bye week]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201010170chi.htm |title=Seattle Seahawks at Chicago Bears - October 17th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201010240chi.htm |title=Washington Redskins at Chicago Bears - October 24th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> [[File:Cutler Quinnan8 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Cutler in 2010]]
Martz retooled the offensive line and showed more commitment to the running game, allowing Cutler to escape the next three games with just six sacks total. He won those three, followed by then-career-bests of four touchdowns and rating of 146.2 in a win over the 7–3 [[Philadelphia Eagles|Eagles]] (winning NFC Player of the Week), and an 80.8% completion percentage in a win over [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201011280chi.htm |title=Philadelphia Eagles at Chicago Bears - November 28th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201012050det.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Detroit Lions - December 5th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2010/week_12.htm |title=2010 NFL Week 12 Leaders & Scores |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> After a 152-yard, no touchdown, two interception loss to [[New England Patriots|New England]], Cutler won back-to-back games with three touchdowns, one interception, and 100+ ratings in each, before dropping the season finale to [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201012120chi.htm |title=New England Patriots at Chicago Bears - December 12th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201101020gnb.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Green Bay Packers - January 2nd, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The Bears finished with an 11–5 record, an [[NFC North]] title, and a first-round bye. Despite taking a league-leading 52 sacks, Cutler finished the season with 3,274 passing yards, 23 touchdowns, 16 interceptions, 232 rushing yards, and 4 comeback victories.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/CutlJa00/gamelog/2010 |title=Jay Cutler 2010 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
[[File:Jay Cutler vs Packers.jpg|left|thumb|Cutler on January 2, 2011 against the [[Green Bay Packers]].]]
In Cutler's playoff debut against the [[Seattle Seahawks]], he had 274 passing yards, two passing touchdowns, 43 rushing yards, and two rushing touchdowns in the Bears 35–24 win, making him the second quarterback in NFL history since [[Otto Graham]] in 1954 and 1955 to score two touchdown passes and two touchdown runs in a playoff game.<ref>{{cite web|last=McCauley|first=Janie|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2013/0114/Colin-Kaepernick-sets-off-the-Kaepernicking-craze-video|title=Colin Kaepernick sets off the 'Kaepernicking craze' (+video)|publisher=''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''|date=2013-01-14|accessdate=2013-01-14}}</ref>
In the NFC Championship Game, Cutler completed 6-of-14 passes for 80 yards and an interception, before a knee injury sidelined him early in the third quarter of a 21–14 loss to [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.profootballweekly.com/2011/01/23/long-offseason-ahead-for-bears-qb-cutler |title=Long offseason ahead for Bears QB Cutler |publisher=ProFootballWeekly.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324030836/http://www.profootballweekly.com/2011/01/23/long-offseason-ahead-for-bears-qb-cutler |archivedate=March 24, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Bears did not make an immediate announcement about Cutler's condition, allowing speculation to grow.<ref name="haugh" /> In possibly the NFL’s first player-on-player [[social media]] attack, Cutler was being criticized seconds after the injury by [[Maurice Jones-Drew]], [[Darnell Dockett]], [[Deion Sanders]], and [[Mark Schlereth]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Dan |last=Wetzel |title=Unprecedented social media attack dooms Cutler |date=January 24, 2011 |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=AkQd7Nj_5guzPbMPpEjc1EZDubYF?slug=dw-cutlersocialmedia012411 |work=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=January 25, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124233153/http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=dw-cutlersocialmedia012411 |archivedate=January 24, 2011 |quote=This was, perhaps, the NFL’s first player-on-player social media attack. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Farrar |first=Doug |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/blog/shutdown_corner/post/Cutler-s-NFL-contemporaries-go-after-him-on-Twit?urn=nfl-311321 |title=Cutler's NFL contemporaries go after him on Twitter - Shutdown Corner - NFL Blog - Yahoo! Sports |publisher=Sports.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Mike |last=Freeman |title=Does Cutler have seriously injured knee or weak heart? |date=January 23, 2011 |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/14590417/does-cutler-have-seriously-injured-knee-or-weak-heart |work=CBS Sports.com |accessdate=January 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130210421/http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/story/14590417/does-cutler-have-seriously-injured-knee-or-weak-heart |archivedate=January 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Bears coach [[Lovie Smith]] later clarified that he, and not Cutler, made the decision after consulting the medical and training staff.<ref name="haugh">{{cite news | first = David | last = Haugh | title = Don't question Cutler's toughness | date = January 23, 2011 | url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/ct-spt-0124-bears-haugh-chicago--20110123,0,5643898.column | work = [[Chicago Tribune]] | accessdate =January 24, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Sean | last = Leahy | title = Jay Cutler under attack for leaving Bears' loss with knee injury | date = January 23, 2011 | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2011/01/jay-cutler-under-attack-for-leaving-bears-loss-with-knee-injury/1 | work = USA Today | accessdate =January 24, 2011}}</ref> The following day, an MRI revealed Cutler had sprained his [[Medial collateral ligament|MCL]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/news/story?id=6054047 |title=NFL playoffs: Chicago Bears' Jay Cutler suffered MCL sprain vs. Green Bay Packers - ESPN Chicago |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=January 25, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] quarterback [[Troy Aikman]] commented that the widespread reaction reflected hostility towards Cutler's career-long polarizing attitude.<ref>{{cite news | first = Richard| last = Sandomir | title = When Talking Toughness, Aikman Believes in Cutler | date = January 25, 2011 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/25/sports/football/25nfl.html?scp=1&sq=cutler%20aikman&st=cse | newspaper = The New York Times | accessdate =January 27, 2011|quote=To Aikman, the vitriolic reaction to Cutler was about the attitude he has shown since he arrived in the league.}}</ref> Bears teammates defended Cutler, and his critics themselves became the targets of insults from other players, including Packers [[Aaron Rodgers]] ("disrespectful"),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yardbarker.com/nfl/articles/rodgers_calls_cutler_criticism_disrespectful/4041775 |title=Rodgers calls Cutler criticism 'disrespectful' |publisher=Yardbarker.com |date=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> [[LeRoy Butler]] ("stupid"),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2011/09/23/butler-cutlers-critics-are-stupid/ |title=Butler: Cutler’s Critics Are ‘Stupid’ « CBS Chicago |publisher=Chicago.cbslocal.com |date=September 23, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> and [[B. J. Raji]] ("pretty wrong and a lot times it has a lot to do with jealousy").<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/25/bears-jay-cutler-critics_n_813654.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Bears Fire Back At Jay Cutler's Critics | date=January 25, 2011}}</ref>
====2011 season==== Throughout 2011, offensive coordinator [[Mike Martz]] was commonly criticized for aggressive play-calling in a pass-happy offense, leading to unnecessary wear on a quarterback returning from injury. In the season opener against the Atlanta Falcons, Cutler started the season off on a good note with 312 passing yards, two touchdowns, and one interception in the 30–12 win.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109110chi.htm |title=Atlanta Falcons at Chicago Bears - September 11th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In Week 2 against the [[New Orleans Saints]], Cutler was sacked 6 times and [[New Orleans Saints bounty scandal|kicked in the throat]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Wright |first=Michael C. |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4675326/bears-wonder-if-saints-targeted-them |title=Bears wonder if Saints targeted them |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=January 2, 2010 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> During Week 6, Cutler was caught on microphone asking a player to go to Martz on the sideline, and "tell him I said fuck him!"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nfl.si.com/2011/10/19/jay-cutler-on-cursing-out-mike-martz-things-happen/ |title=Jay Cutler on cursing out Mike Martz: ‘Things Happen’ – Audibles |publisher=Nfl.si.com |date=October 19, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111021042336/http://nfl.si.com/2011/10/19/jay-cutler-on-cursing-out-mike-martz-things-happen/ |archivedate=October 21, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Despite these incidents, by Week 10, Cutler had a middle-of-the-pack QB rating of 85.7 (12th in the league) and the Bears were 6–3. However, on November 20, Cutler broke the thumb on his throwing hand tackling San Diego's [[Antoine Cason]] after an interception. He played through the final drive for the win, but the injury required season-ending surgery.<ref>[http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/7264419/chicago-bears-jay-cutler-surgery-fractured-thumb Jay Cutler to have thumb surgery] ESPN Chicago, November 21, 2011</ref> Under backups [[Caleb Hanie]] and [[Josh McCown]], the Bears lost six of their remaining seven games, and missed the playoffs. Overall, in his shortened 2011 season, Cutler had 2,319 passing yards, 13 touchdowns, and seven interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/CutlJa00/gamelog/2011 |title=Jay Cutler 2011 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
====2012 season==== Before the season, the Bears replaced Martz with [[Mike Tice]], hired Cutler's former coach [[Jeremy Bates (American football)|Jeremy Bates]] from the Broncos,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/ChalkTalkStory.asp?story_id=8619 |title=Cutler is thrilled to reunite with Bates |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date=February 7, 2012 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> and acquired his former teammate, wide receiver [[Brandon Marshall]] from the [[Miami Dolphins]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82791ddb/article/dolphins-ship-wr-marshall-to-bears-in-blockbuster-trade |title=Dolphins ship WR Marshall to Bears in blockbuster trade |publisher=NFL.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> Unlike Martz, Tice allowed Cutler to call audibles at the line of scrimmage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82916104/article/chicago-bears-jay-cutler-allowed-to-audible-again?module=HP11_headline_stack |title=Chicago Bears' Jay Cutler allowed to audible again |publisher=NFL.com |date=May 14, 2012 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Jay Cutler and Brandon Marshall.jpg|thumb|Cutler talking to [[Brandon Marshall]] at Bears Training Camp in 2012]] Cutler started his season by throwing an interception returned for a touchdown by the [[Indianapolis Colts|Colts']] [[Jerrell Freeman]]. He bounced back from a miserable 1st quarter (passer rating 4.9)<ref>{{cite web|last=Wright |first=Michael C. |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4677791/halftime-bears-24-colts-14 |title=Halftime: Bears 24, Colts 14 - Chicago Bears - ESPN Chicago |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012}}</ref> to finish the game 21-of-35 for 333 yards, two touchdowns, and a 98.9 passer rating, in a 41–21 victory.<ref>{{cite web |last=Mayer |first=Larry |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Explosive-Bears-outduel-Colts/fe5509a2-6877-4304-b4d7-4f66279b9724 |title=Explosive Bears outduel Colts |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912020208/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Explosive-Bears-outduel-Colts/fe5509a2-6877-4304-b4d7-4f66279b9724 |archive-date=2012-09-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In a frustrating week 2, Cutler was sacked 7 times and threw 4 interceptions against [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]], yelling at his porous offensive line and bumping left tackle [[J'Marcus Webb]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Larry |first=Mayer |url=http://blog.chicagobears.com/2012/09/17/players-react-to-cutlerwebb-incident/ |title=Write Now Blog | Players react to Cutler/Webb incident |publisher=Blog.chicagobears.com |date= |accessdate=September 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922152632/http://blog.chicagobears.com/2012/09/17/players-react-to-cutlerwebb-incident/ |archivedate=September 22, 2012 |df= }}</ref> on his way to a 28.2 passer rating in a 23–10 loss.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer |first=Larry |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-lose-to-Packers-23-10-at-Lambeau/c9db8a80-11ca-4f1a-9be0-fd62c8e0a403 |title=Bears lose to Packers 23-10 at Lambeau |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date= |accessdate=September 15, 2012}}</ref> The line responded by surrendering just 5 sacks in the next three games, all wins, the second a 34-18 win over [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] where Cutler was 18 of 24 for 275 yards, two touchdowns, no interceptions, and the third-best passer rating of his career (140.1).<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer |first=Larry |url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Cutler-lauds-offensive-line-Mike-Tice-/5a247135-cea4-4899-a7e7-4b59044cef46 |title=Cutler lauds offensive line, Mike Tice |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date= |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref> After unspectacular performances in close wins over [[Detroit Lions|Detroit]] and [[Carolina Panthers|Carolina]], Cutler had three touchdowns and no interceptions with a rating of 138.1 in a 51–20 blowout of [[Tennessee Titans|Tennessee]], bringing the Bears to 7–1 on the season, and Cutler's personal record in games with a 100+ QB rating to 25–0.<ref>This win, combined with {{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/chalk-talk/article-1/Is-Cutler-undefeated-with-100-passer-rating/8e3a69dc-04dd-4bc7-8cc9-e3000b2cfd83 |title=Is Cutler undefeated with 100+ passer rating? |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date= |accessdate=October 3, 2012}}</ref>
In Week 10 against the [[Houston Texans]], Cutler joined [[Michael Vick]] and [[Alex Smith]] as the third NFL quarterback out with a concussion that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000093603/article/jay-cutler-gets-concussion-in-bears-loss-to-texans|title=Jay Cutler gets concussion in Chicago Bears' loss|work=[[National Football League]]|date=November 11, 2012|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}</ref> His replacement [[Jason Campbell]] lost that game and the next.<ref>{{cite web|last=Seligman|first=Andrew|url=https://news.yahoo.com/bears-cutler-miss-49ers-game-concussion-175944644--nfl.html|title=Bears' Cutler to miss 49ers game with concussion|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=November 16, 2012|accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref> Cutler returned for a Week 12 win over the [[Minnesota Vikings]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hanzus|first=Dan|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000099771/article/reports-jay-cutler-cleared-will-start-for-chicago-bears|title=Reports: Jay Cutler cleared, will start for Chicago Bears|work=[[National Football League]]|date=November 24, 2012|accessdate=November 24, 2012}}</ref> Despite a 119.6 passer rating against the [[Seattle Seahawks]] in week 13, the Bears lost in overtime,<ref>{{cite news|last=Biggs|first=Brad|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/ravens/ct-spt-1203-bears-seahawks-chicago--20121203,0,5537075.story?track=rss|title=Bears defense unable to hold off Seahawks|newspaper=[[Baltimore Sun]]|date=December 2, 2012|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> which was followed by two close losses to [[Minnesota Vikings|Minnesota]] and [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]]. Cutler finished the season with two solid performances in easy wins over the [[Arizona Cardinals|Cardinals]] and [[Detroit Lions|Lions]]. Despite a 10–6 record, the Bears missed the playoffs.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/2012.htm |title=2012 Chicago Bears Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref>
Cutler again finished the season in the top 5 for times sacked, but nevertheless lead the league in fourth-quarter passer rating with 114.7.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Reviewing-Bears-season-by-the-numbers/527155e6-2790-458c-a3df-c26aaf2c136c|title=Reviewing Bears season by the numbers|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=January 7, 2013|accessdate=January 7, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006093201/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Reviewing-Bears-season-by-the-numbers/527155e6-2790-458c-a3df-c26aaf2c136c|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In just four seasons, he was already the Bears all-time team leader in passer rating (81.9) and completions (1,034), and second in yards (12,292), touchdowns (82), and completion percentage (59.6%).<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Marc-Trestman-eager-to-begin-working-with-Jay-Cutler/89d2168a-3a54-4d8b-9467-5fb6e899e87a|title=Marc Trestman eager to begin working with Jay Cutler|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=January 17, 2013|accessdate=January 17, 2013}}</ref> His reunion with [[Brandon Marshall]] led to franchise records of 118 receptions for 1,508 yards, and the 7th-year receiver's first [[All-Pro]] selection.<ref>See [https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/single-season-receiving.htm Pro-Football-Reference's Bears Franchise Encyclopedia].</ref>
====2013 season==== New head coach [[Marc Trestman]] developed a successful strategy to better protect his quarterback, and in the first six games Cutler was sacked only 9 times compared to 23, 19, and 19 in the previous three seasons.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Jay-Cutler-lauds-improved-offensive-line/e033bd63-e795-4095-b650-504fb6c3c58e|title=Jay Cutler lauds improved offensive line|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=October 4, 2013|accessdate=October 4, 2013}}</ref> Under the new scheme, Cutler began the season with three consecutive games with a 90+ passer rating for the first time since 2009. In each of those wins, he threw touchdowns in the 4th quarter, including game-winners in week 1 against Cincinnati and week 2 against Minnesota. He threw three interceptions in a week 4 loss to Detroit. In week five, Cutler was sacked three times and fumbled in the first 16 minutes of the game, then rebounded for 358 yards, two touchdowns, and a season-high 128.1 passer rating in defeat.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Critical-mistakes-cost-Bears-in-loss-to-Saints/7a5915cd-6508-4238-baf8-9661f5e8a5ae|title=Critical mistakes cost Bears in loss to Saints|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=October 6, 2013|accessdate=October 6, 2013}}</ref> He threw 2 touchdowns in a Week 6 win over the [[New York Giants]]. Through the first six games, he had a career best 95.2 passer rating, five multiple touchdown games, and a franchise-record 1,630 passing yards.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Trestman-impressed-with-Bears-team-leaders/a7337870-a826-4496-a9c5-89a353fa24c7|title=Trestman impressed with Bears team leaders|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=October 10, 2013|accessdate=October 11, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Paea-hopes-to-return-to-action-Sunday-in-Washington/16b02365-336e-4eb1-98de-6d90152dad42|title=Paea hopes to return to action Sunday in Washington|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=October 16, 2013|accessdate=October 16, 2013}}</ref>
However, against the [[2013 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] the following week, his 100th career start, Cutler tore a groin muscle when sacked by [[Chris Baker (defensive lineman)|Chris Baker]], breaking [[Jim Harbaugh]]'s franchise record for most times sacked.<ref>{{cite web|last=Elholm|first=Eric|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/jay-cutler-leaves-game-being-sacked-grabbing-left-181810975--nfl.html|title=Jay Cutler knocked out against Washington Redskins with groin injury|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=October 20, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gartman|first=Michael|url=http://gridirongrit.com/2013/10/chicago-bears-qb-jay-cutler-goes-down-with-gruesome-injury/|title=Chicago Bears QB Jay Cutler Goes Down With Gruesome Injury|publisher=Gridiron Grit|date=October 20, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026051533/http://gridirongrit.com/2013/10/chicago-bears-qb-jay-cutler-goes-down-with-gruesome-injury/|archivedate=October 26, 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wright|first=Michael|url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/9858963/jay-cutler-chicago-bears-quarterback-least-four-weeks|title=Jay Cutler tears muscle in groin|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=October 21, 2013|accessdate=October 21, 2013}}</ref> Josh McCown was solid in relief, barely losing that Redskins game in a 45–41 shootout, and after the bye-week tossing two touchdowns in a 27–21 win at Green Bay.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chicago Bears at Green Bay Packers - November 4th, 2013|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201311040gnb.htm|website=Pro-Football-Reference.com|language=en}}</ref> Cutler was medically cleared to return early for the week 10 game against Detroit,<ref>{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Rich|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-cutler-practicing-bears-20131107,0,3058376.story|title=Cutler cleared to play, expected to start vs. Lions|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=November 7, 2013|accessdate=November 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131108014314/http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-cutler-practicing-bears-20131107,0,3058376.story|archivedate=November 8, 2013|df=}}</ref> where he had 250 yards, one touchdown, and one interception before a hit from [[Stephen Tulloch]] in the second quarter finally drove him from the game on the Bears last drive.<ref name="Ankle injury" /> McCown drove 74 yards in 90 seconds for a touchdown, but the two-point conversion failed and the Bears lost 21–19.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-late-comeback-falls-short-against-Lions/dc3e9c3c-ace2-4a29-a5e1-cc4d38b07aef|title=Bears' late comeback falls short against Lions|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=November 10, 2013|accessdate=November 10, 2013}}</ref>
Cutler missed the next four games with his injury and McCown played well in his absence, leading to some controversy when Cutler was reinstated as the starting QB in Week 15.<ref name="Ankle injury">{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Cutler-expected-to-be-sidelined-with-ankle-injury/cad4be8b-fbd2-49cc-bd58-08d883623e41|title=Cutler expected to be sidelined with ankle injury|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=November 11, 2013|accessdate=November 11, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306203506/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Cutler-expected-to-be-sidelined-with-ankle-injury/cad4be8b-fbd2-49cc-bd58-08d883623e41|archivedate=March 6, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Rich |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-trestman-optimistic-cutler-will-start-20131211,0,717154.story|title=Barring a setback, Cutler to start vs. Browns|publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=December 11, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hanzus|first=Dan|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000284138/article/jay-cutler-ankle-to-miss-week-12-for-chicago-bears|title=Jay Cutler (ankle) to miss Week 12 for Chicago Bears|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=November 18, 2013|accessdate=November 18, 2013}}</ref> Cutler threw two interceptions in the first half against the [[Cleveland Browns]], one returned for a touchdown, but ended with a 102.2 passer rating and three touchdowns.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Cutler-thrives-under-pressure/ab910148-b1ba-40b4-a0b0-389a98ad41c6|title=Cutler thrives under pressure|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=December 21, 2013|accessdate=December 21, 2013}}</ref> In the next week's 54–11 loss to the [[Philadelphia Eagles]], Cutler ended up with 14,687 career passing yards for the Bears, one more than [[Sid Luckman]]'s franchise record.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/sports/2013/12/22/mccoy-eagles-rout-bears/|title=McCoy, Eagles rout Bears|work=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=December 23, 2013|accessdate=December 23, 2013}}</ref> The season finale was a winner-takes-the-division matchup at home against Green Bay.
