Despite Cutler's 15-of-24 passing for 226 yards, two touchdowns, and one interception for a 103.8 passer rating, the Bears lost 33–28 on a last-minute Hail Mary, missing the playoffs with an 8–8 record.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Jeff|title=Rodgers sends Pack to playoffs with late TD|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2013/12/29/5254636/bears-packers-2013-final-score-recap|work=SBNation.com|date=29 Dec 2013}}</ref> Cutler ended the season completing 224 of 355 passes for 2,621 yards, 19 touchdowns, 12 interceptions, and a career-high 89.2 passer rating.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Postgame-notes-Bears-vs-Packers/c6377bfc-92f4-4243-8ed1-7dc397b4ae64|title=Postgame notes: Bears vs. Packers|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=December 29, 2013|accessdate=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101042304/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Postgame-notes-Bears-vs-Packers/c6377bfc-92f4-4243-8ed1-7dc397b4ae64|archive-date=2014-01-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/CutlJa00/gamelog/2013 |title=Jay Cutler 2013 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
On January 2, 2014, Cutler signed a seven-year deal, keeping him with the Bears through the 2020 NFL season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2014/01/02/bears-sign-jay-cutler-to-a-7-year-contract/|title=Bears Sign Jay Cutler To 7-Year Contract|work=[[WBBM-TV]]|date=January 2, 2014|accessdate=January 2, 2014}}</ref>
====2014 season==== [[File:Cutler-family-night2014.jpg|thumb|Marc Trestman looks on as Cutler practices in 2014.]] Cutler and the Bears struggled to a 5–11 record in Trestman's second year as head coach.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/chi/2014.htm |title=2014 Chicago Bears Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The Bears opened the season with an overtime loss to the [[Buffalo Bills]], in which Cutler threw two touchdowns and interceptions for 349 yards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409070chi.htm |title=Buffalo Bills at Chicago Bears - September 7th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The next week, the team overcame a 17-point deficit behind Cutler's four touchdown passes to defeat the [[San Francisco 49ers]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409140sfo.htm |title=Chicago Bears at San Francisco 49ers - September 14th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The next week, he led the Bears to a 27–19 victory against the [[New York Jets]], tallying 225 passing yards, two touchdowns and no interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409220nyj.htm |title=Chicago Bears at New York Jets - September 22nd, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
In both weeks 4 and 5, Cutler threw two touchdowns and two interceptions in defeats to the Packers and Panthers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409280chi.htm |title=Green Bay Packers at Chicago Bears - September 28th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201410050car.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Carolina Panthers - October 5th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In week 6, Cutler recorded a career-high 381 passing yards, defeating [[Atlanta Falcons|Atlanta]] 27–13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nfl/preview?gameId=400554270|title=Dolphins-Bears Preview|work=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}</ref> Cutler recorded just 190 yards in a loss to Miami, then threw three touchdowns but suffered a lopsided 51–23 defeat to the [[New England Patriots]], and threw two interceptions in an even worse 55–14 loss to the Packers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201410190chi.htm |title=Miami Dolphins at Chicago Bears - October 19th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201410260nwe.htm |title=Chicago Bears at New England Patriots - October 26th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201411090gnb.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Green Bay Packers - November 9th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The 3–6 Bears drew criticism from former Bears linebacker [[Brian Urlacher]], who suggested that [[Phil Emery (American football)|Phil Emery]] shouldn't have re-signed Cutler. "Financially, he is one of the elite guys in the NFL... He just hasn't produced like an elite quarterback."<ref>{{cite news |last=Dickerson |first=Jeff |url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/11749420/brian-urlacher-jay-cutler-chicago-bears-elite-qb-salary-only |title=Urlacher: Jay Cutler hasn't produced |work=[[ESPN]].com |date=2014-10-24 |accessdate=2014-12-18 }}</ref>
Cutler and the Bears rebounded with two consecutive wins. He threw three touchdowns, two interceptions, and 330 yards against the Vikings, and 130 yards and one passing touchdown against Tampa Bay.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201411160chi.htm |title=Minnesota Vikings at Chicago Bears - November 16th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201411230chi.htm |title=Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Chicago Bears - November 23rd, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> That would be the last win of the season. Cutler started the Thanksgiving Day game against Detroit with two passing touchdowns, but the Bears stumbled for the remainder of the game ''en route'' to 34–17 loss. He finished the game with two touchdowns, two interceptions, and 280 yards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201411270det.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Detroit Lions - November 27th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The Bears suffered their eighth loss of the season to the [[Dallas Cowboys]], in which Cutler threw 341 yards, two touchdowns and one interception, mathematically eliminating the Bears from the playoffs.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412040chi.htm |title=Dallas Cowboys at Chicago Bears - December 4th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Under criticism, offensive coordinator [[Aaron Kromer]] partially blamed Cutler's audibles and impromptu play calling for the poor record, but later apologized to Cutler and the Bears organization in a press conference.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rosenthal |first=Gregg |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000442582/article/aaron-kromer-apologizes-for-criticizing-jay-cutler |title=Aaron Kromer apologizes for criticizing Jay Cutler |work=[[NFL]].com |date=2014-12-12 |accessdate=2014-12-18 }}</ref> The next week, Cutler threw two touchdowns, three interceptions, and just 194 yards for a season-low 55.8 passer rating in a loss to the Saints.<ref name="tres-fc">{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Michael |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4696500/marc-trestman-admits-failures-with-jay-cutler |title=Marc Trestman admits failures with Jay Cutler |work=[[ESPN]].com |date=2014-12-17 |accessdate=2014-12-18 }}</ref> Trestman demoted Cutler in favor of [[Jimmy Clausen]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Michael |url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/12043769/chicago-bears-start-jimmy-clausen-jay-cutler-week |title=Bears giving Jimmy Clausen start |work=[[ESPN]].com |date=2014-12-17 |accessdate=2014-12-18 }}</ref> but Cutler returned when Clausen suffered a concussion in the loss to Detroit. In the Bears' season finale against the Vikings, Cutler completed 23 of 36 passes for 172 yards, and a 63 passer rating in the loss.<ref>{{cite news |last=Peters |first=Micah |url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/12/bears-quarterback-jimmy-clausen-was-furious-after-brutal-helmet-to-helmet-hit |title=Bears quarterback Jimmy Clausen was furious after brutal helmet-to-helmet hit |work=[[USA Today]] |date=2014-12-21 |accessdate=2014-12-30 }}</ref> He accrued 3,812 passing yards, a career-high 28 passing touchdowns, but led the NFL with 18 interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/CutlJa00/gamelog/2014 |title=Jay Cutler 2014 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
====2015 season==== The Bears hired [[John Fox (American football)|John Fox]] as their new head coach on January 19. Both Fox and GM [[Ryan Pace]] were initially lukewarm on Cutler,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wesseling|first1=Chris|title=John Fox looking forward to getting to know Jay Cutler|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000460797/article/john-fox-looking-forward-to-getting-to-know-jay-cutler|work=NFL.com|date=19 Jan 2015|language=en}}</ref> but reluctantly decided to keep Cutler as the starter.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Patra|first1=Kevin|title=Bears GM: Jay Cutler is our starting quarterback|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000478234/article/bears-gm-jay-cutler-is-our-starting-quarterback|work=NFL.com|date=11 Mar 2015|language=en}}</ref> [[Tight end]] [[Martellus Bennett]] indicated his teammates were similarly unenthusiastic.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Heck|first1=Jordan|title=Bears' Martellus Bennett takes swing at Jay Cutler's leadership|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/news/martellus-bennett-jay-cutler-leadership-chicago-bears-marc-trestman/s1w9chtb076g18sjbv1y1jdd9|work=Sporting News|date=25 August 2015}}</ref>
Cutler began the season with a lackluster 225 yards in a loss to Green Bay, tossing a last-minute touchdown to Bennett to bring his rating up to 67.5.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201509130chi.htm |title=Green Bay Packers at Chicago Bears - September 13th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> He began Week 2 against the Cardinals with 8 straight completions, but then threw an interception and injured his hamstring failing to stop safety [[Tony Jefferson]] from returning it for a touchdown.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brinson|first1=Will|title=Jay Cutler's pick-6 leads to his Week 2 ending with injured hamstring|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/jay-cutlers-pick-6-leads-to-his-week-2-ending-with-injured-hamstring/|work=CBSSports.com|date=20 Sep 2015|language=en}}</ref> Without Cutler, the Bears lost 48-23 to the Cardinals, and were shutout 26–0 in Week 3 at Seattle.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201509270sea.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Seattle Seahawks - September 27th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> Cutler returned against Oakland, throwing two first half touchdowns, and drove 48 yards in the last 2:05 to set-up a game-winning field goal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201510040chi.htm |title=Oakland Raiders at Chicago Bears - October 4th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In Week 5, Cutler threw two touchdowns in the final 3:05 for a dramatic 18–17 victory over the Chiefs and a tie of [[Jim McMahon]]'s record for the most wins in team history.<ref>{{cite news|last=Finley|first=Patrick|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-football/7/71/1021932/jay-cutler-ties-punky-qbs-wins-record|title=Jay Cutler ties Jim McMahon's Bears wins record|newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=October 11, 2015|accessdate=October 11, 2015}}</ref> In Week 6, Cutler was just short of a third consecutive comeback: despite a season-best 353 yards, a 4th quarter touchdown and 2-point conversion, followed by a 69-yard drive in 17 seconds for a game-tying field goal, the Bears lost in overtime to the Lions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201510180det.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Detroit Lions - October 18th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> After the bye, in Week 8 Cutler again scored a go-ahead touchdown late in the 4th quarter, but the Vikings rallied for two late scores and a 23–20 win.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201511010chi.htm |title=Minnesota Vikings at Chicago Bears - November 1st, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In Week 9 against [[San Diego Chargers|San Diego]], Cutler threw yet another late 4th quarter touchdown, which both won the game 22–19, and set the Bears franchise record (139).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bien|first1=Louis|title=Bears win in yet another Monday night thriller|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2015/11/9/9702342/chargers-bears-2015-results-monday-night-football-score|website=SBNation.com|date=9 November 2015}}</ref> In Week 10, Cutler had a stellar performance in a 37–13 win St. Louis, going 19-for-24 for 258 yards, three touchdowns (two of them for 80+ yards for the only time in franchise history)<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/ptd_finder.cgi?request=1&match=game&year_min=1920&year_max=2016&team_id=chi&game_type=R&game_num_min=0&game_num_max=99&week_num_min=0&week_num_max=99&td_type=pass&group_by_pass=qb&distance_min=80&distance_max=100&quarter=1&quarter=2&quarter=3&quarter=4&quarter=5&scorer_age_min=0&scorer_age_max=0&passer_age_min=0&passer_age_max=0&order_by=game_date List] of Bears' 80+ yard TD passes</ref> and no interceptions; his 151.0 passer rating was a career-best, and the best by a Bears QB since 1980.<ref>[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/pgl_finder.cgi?request=1&match=game&year_min=1950&year_max=2016&season_start=1&season_end=-1&age_min=0&age_max=0&pos=0&game_type=R&team_id=chi&career_game_num_min=0&career_game_num_max=499&game_num_min=0&game_num_max=99&week_num_min=0&week_num_max=99&c1stat=pass_att&c1comp=gt&c1val=10&c2stat=pass_rating&c2comp=gt&c2val=130&c3stat=choose&c3comp=gt&c4stat=choose&c4comp=gt&c5comp=choose&c5gtlt=lt&c6mult=1.0&c6comp=choose&order_by=pass_rating List] of Bears games where a QBs had a passer rating >130 (min. 10 attempts).</ref>
That would be the season high-point for both the 4–5 Bears and Cutler. The Bears went 2–5 the rest of the season, four of the losses by less than 7 points. Cutler had three unremarkable games in narrow losses to Denver and San Francisco and a narrow win at Green Bay. In Week 14, Cutler threw for 315 yards and two touchdowns against Washington, including a 50-yard completion with two minutes remaining, but [[Robbie Gould]] missed the game-tying field goal for a 24–21 loss.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201512130chi.htm |title=Washington Redskins at Chicago Bears - December 13th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The next week, Cutler was sacked five times and threw an interception in a 38–17 loss to Minnesota,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201512200min.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Minnesota Vikings - December 20th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> then had just 156 yards but a 100.2 passer rating in a win over Tampa Bay.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201512270tam.htm |title=Chicago Bears at Tampa Bay Buccaneers - December 27th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> In the season finale against Detroit, Cutler had two touchdowns, but three interceptions including one deep in Lions territory at the 2 minute warning to seal the 24–20 loss.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201601030chi.htm |title=Detroit Lions at Chicago Bears - January 3rd, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref>
Despite his receiving unit being plagued by injuries, Cutler had one of his best seasons as he ended 2015 with 3,629 passing yards, 21 touchdowns, 11 interceptions,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/gallery/chicago-bears-2015-season-recap-010516|title=Chicago Bears Season in Review|work=[[Foxsports.com]]|date=January 5, 2016|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref> and career highs in passer rating (92.3)<ref>{{cite web|last=Kaberon|first=Eli|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-bythenumbers/By-the-Numbers-2015/c1660e9e-fb2a-4649-806c-ab92e93a1412|title=By the Numbers: 2015|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=January 6, 2016|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref> and completion percentage (64.4). The 11 interceptions were the lowest in his career<ref name="QB review">{{cite web|last=Stoltz|first=Jeremy|url=http://www.scout.com/nfl/bears/story/1630371-bears-2015-season-review-quarterback|title=Bears 2015 Season Review: Quarterback|publisher=[[Scout.com]]|date=January 7, 2016|accessdate=January 11, 2016}}</ref> and resulted in an interception percentage of 2.3, the lowest in a season when he has started at least 12 games,<ref name="Inside the Numbers: Adam Gase">{{cite web|last=Poupart|first=Alain|url=http://www.miamidolphins.com/news/article-1/INSIDE-THE-NUMBERS-Adam-Gase/3e7c7c44-7cd4-4ff8-9a8f-41783988deda|title=INSIDE THE NUMBERS: Adam Gase|publisher=[[Miami Dolphins]]|date=January 11, 2016|accessdate=January 11, 2016}}</ref> while 21 touchdowns were his second-most since 2011 and the 3,629 yards were the third-most in his career.<ref name="QB review" /> On third down, Cutler had a 103.2 passer rating (fourth in the NFL) after completing 91 of 141 passes for 1,242 yards, seven touchdowns and two interceptions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-offense-in-NFL-Rankings/04b36127-0415-491d-b6ee-cf424e8a5fa3|title=Bears offense in NFL Rankings|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016}}</ref>
====2016 season==== With [[Adam Gase]]'s departure to become the head coach of the Miami Dolphins, [[Dowell Loggains]] became the Bears' offensive coordinator.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lambert |first=Erik |url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/jay-cutler-failure-came-down-to-tragic-coaching-losses-112116 |title=Jay Cutler Failure Came Down To Tragic Coaching Losses |work=[[Fox Sports]] |date=2016-11-29 |accessdate=2016-12-06 }}</ref> In Cutler's first two games, he was sacked 8 times and had two interceptions in losses to the [[Houston Texans]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Dickerson |first=Jeff |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4703634/chemistry-problems-between-jay-cutler-kevin-white-plague-bears-in-houston |title=Chemistry problems between Jay Cutler, Kevin White plague Bears in Houston |work=[[ESPN]] |date=2016-09-11 |accessdate=2016-12-06 }}</ref> (where he injured his right thumb but completed the game),<ref name="thumb2016">{{cite news |last=Jahns |first=Adam |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/sports/jay-cutler-played-with-ligament-damage-in-thumb-from-texans-game/ |title=Jay Cutler played with ligament damage in thumb from Texans game |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=2016-09-20 |accessdate=2016-12-06 }}</ref> and [[Philadelphia Eagles]] (where he re-aggravated his injury and was replaced by [[Brian Hoyer]]).<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-gamerecap/Bears-drop-to-0-2-with-loss-to-Eagles/0f30f242-9a87-4427-bb35-a668fa4d8312|title=Bears drop to 0-2 with loss to Eagles|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=September 19, 2016|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> He missed the next five games before making his return against the Vikings, where he completed 20 of 31 passes for 252 yards, a touchdown and a 100.5 passer rating en route to a 20–10 victory.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-gamerecap/Bears-dominate-up-front-beat-Vikings/f0726a54-bcca-43b2-8658-a3c87066d1ba|title=Bears dominate up front, beat Vikings|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=October 31, 2016|accessdate=November 6, 2016}}</ref> [[Zach Miller (tight end, born 1984)|Zach Miller]] praised Cutler's performance in his return, even adding that he delivered a half-time speech to motivate his teammates.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/bears-zach-miller-jay-cutler-120846225.html |title=Bears' Zach Miller: Jay Cutler 'is the emotion on the football field' |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |date=2016-11-01 |accessdate=2016-11-18 }}</ref> Cutler fumbled and threw two interceptions (including a pick-6) in a loss to [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay]].<ref name="tb11">{{cite news |last=Dickerson |first=Jeff |url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/18074504/jay-cutler-denies-lost-support-bears-teammates-bucs-loss |title=Jay Cutler denies he has lost support of Bears teammates after Bucs loss |work=[[ESPN]] |date=2016-11-17 |accessdate=2016-11-18 }}</ref> Cutler sustained a labrum injury in his throwing shoulder on November 20, 2016 in a loss to the Giants, and missed the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cutler out for season with injury|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Cutler-out-for-season-with-injury/11d7c912-34fc-4eeb-bbf7-d122ec28ad55|author=Mayer, Larry|website=ChicagoBears.com|date=December 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bears add veteran Banks to secondary|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-rostermoves/Bears-add-veteran-Banks-to-secondary/5183b4e6-ce2d-4bd8-befc-765f74550a2c|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170212031110/http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-rostermoves/Bears-add-veteran-Banks-to-secondary/5183b4e6-ce2d-4bd8-befc-765f74550a2c|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 12, 2017|author=Mayer, Larry|website=ChicagoBears.com|date=December 5, 2016}}</ref> In his five games in 2016, Cutler recorded 1,059 passing yards, four touchdowns, five interceptions, and a 78.1 [[passer rating]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Dickerson |first=Jeff |url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/18181048/chicago-bears-quarterback-jay-cutler-shoulder-surgery-headed-injured-reserve |title=Bears QB Jay Cutler to have season-ending shoulder surgery |work=[[ESPN]] |date=2016-12-01 |accessdate=2016-12-06 }}</ref>
On March 9, 2017, Cutler was released by the Bears through a $2 million [[buyout clause]], after the guaranteed years in his seven-year contract had run out. After Cutler's lackluster performances and injuries, the move had been expected for months, as the Bears had decided to award a $45 million contract to [[Mike Glennon]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Patra|first=Kevin|title=Chicago Bears Chicago Bears release quarterback Jay Cutler|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000791875/article/chicago-bears-releasing-quarterback-jay-cutler|website=NFL.com|date=March 9, 2017}}</ref> In May 2017, Cutler announced his retirement from professional football and was hired by FOX Sports to be a commentator.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Orr|first1=Conor|title=Jay Cutler joins FOX Sports|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000806602/article/jay-cutler-to-join-fox-sports-as-a-broadcaster|publisher=NFL|accessdate=May 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Patra|first1=Kevin|title=Jay Cutler's broadcasting move different than Romo's|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000806633/article/jay-cutlers-broadcasting-move-different-than-romos|publisher=NFL|accessdate=May 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Patra|first1=Kevin|title=Cutler: Retirement, move to broadcasting 'permanent'|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000806746/article/cutler-retirement-move-to-broadcasting-permanent|publisher=NFL|accessdate=May 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Miami Dolphins=== On August 3, 2017, [[Miami Dolphins]] quarterback [[Ryan Tannehill]] suffered a season-ending injury, and the team reached out to the retired Cutler.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/08/03/dolphins-ryan-tannehill-appears-injured-during-11-on-11-drill-walks-off-gingerly/|title=‘He’s done, I think’: Dolphins reportedly fear Ryan Tannehill needs season-ending surgery|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref> On August 7, Cutler signed a one-year, $10 million contract with the Dolphins, reuniting him with former Bears offensive coordinator Adam Gase, who had been hired as Miami's head coach in [[2016 Miami Dolphins season|2016]].<ref name=Dolphins>{{cite web|title=Dolphins Make Roster Moves|url=http://www.miamidolphins.com/news/article-1/Dolphins-Make-Roster-Moves/9bd65add-dd07-43b1-b060-e918adfac8fe|website=MiamiDolphins.com|date=August 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jay Cutler agrees to one-year deal with Miami Dolphins|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000826497/article/jay-cutler-agrees-to-oneyear-10m-deal-with-dolphins|author=Orr, Conor|website=NFL.com|date=August 7, 2017}}</ref>
In Week 2, the Dolphins won their first game against the [[Los Angeles Chargers]], 19–17. Cutler was 24-of-33 for 230 yards with a touchdown to wide receiver [[Kenny Stills]] in the road victory.<ref>{{cite web|title=Game Recap: Miami Dolphins defeat LA Chargers|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/nfl/miami-dolphins/article173866366.html|website=miamiherald.com|date=September 17, 2017}}</ref> In a Week 7 game against the [[2017 New York Jets season|New York Jets]], Cutler suffered multiple cracked ribs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Injuries: Jay Cutler's MRI reveals multiple cracked ribs|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000866028/article/injuries-jay-cutlers-mri-reveals-multiple-cracked-ribs|website=nfl.com|date=October 24, 2017}}</ref> He was replaced by [[Matt Moore (American football)|Matt Moore]] during the game and was ruled out for the following week's game against the [[Baltimore Ravens]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Durbin|first=Jared|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/jay-cutler-officially-declared-out-for-thursday-night-vs-ravens/|title=Jay Cutler officially declared out for Thursday night vs. Ravens|publisher=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=October 25, 2017|accessdate=October 27, 2017}}</ref> He returned in Week 9 to face the [[Oakland Raiders]] on ''Sunday Night Football''. In the 27–24 loss, he was very efficient going 34-of-42 for 311 yards and a touchdown.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201711050mia.htm |title=Oakland Raiders at Miami Dolphins - November 5th, 2017 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> In the Week 11 game, Cutler suffered a concussion, which caused him to miss the team's next game.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/21540981/miami-dolphins-starting-quarterback-jay-cutler-ruled-new-england-patriots-concussion | title=Jay Cutler ruled out vs. Patriots with concussion, Matt Moore to start for Dolphins | publisher=espn.com | date=November 24, 2017 | accessdate=November 26, 2017 | author=Walker, James}}</ref> Cutler had his best performance of the year in a Monday Night Football game against New England where he outplayed Tom Brady and the Dolphins upset the Patriots. Cutler threw three touchdowns in the win. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000891769/article/jay-cutler-outdoes-tom-brady-as-dolphins-beat-patriots|title=Jay Cutler outdoes Tom Brady as Dolphins beat Patriots|publisher=}}</ref>
On December 27, he said he would probably only continue his NFL career if he can be a starter, stating "I wouldn’t want to move again or go somewhere just to back up."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://miami.cbslocal.com/2017/12/27/jay-cutler-discusses-future-doesnt-wish-to-continue-career-as-a-backup/ | title=Jay Cutler Discusses Future: Doesn’t Wish To Continue Career As A Backup | publisher=miami.cbslocal.com | date=December 27, 2017 | accessdate=January 4, 2018 | author=Donno, Alex}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://dolphinswire.usatoday.com/2017/12/27/dolphins-qb-jay-cutler-not-interested-in-backup-role-in-2018/ | title=Dolphins QB Jay Cutler not interested in backup role in 2018 | publisher=dolphinswire.usatoday.com | date=December 27, 2017 | accessdate=January 4, 2018 | author=Staley, Antwan}}</ref> He started 14 games and finished with 2,666 passing yards, 19 touchdowns, and 14 interceptions for the Dolphins in the 2017 season.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/CutlJa00/gamelog/2017 |title=Jay Cutler 2017 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> The Dolphins did not make the playoffs and Cutler went 6-8 as a starter. Many teammates, including [[Kenny Stills]], praised Cutler during the season. “I love the guy,” Stills said. “He’s a good man. People in other places have kind of given him a hard time. I got to know him as a man and as a player and I appreciate him. I like him. I’m thankful for the experience of playing with him, catching some balls from him.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailydolphin.blog.palmbeachpost.com/2018/01/01/kenny-stills-says-jay-cutler-bucked-reputation-in-year-with-dolphins/|title=Kenny Stills says Jay Cutler bucked reputation in season with Dolphins - The Daily Dolphin|publisher=}}</ref>

==Personal life== [[file:USMC-060809-F-3695C-074.jpg|thumb|Cutler (#6, top row, far right) with teammates and soldiers at [[Buckley Air Force Base]] in 2006.]] ===Relationships=== Cutler began dating reality television star [[Kristin Cavallari]] in Fall 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20429994,00.html | title=Caught in the Act!| date = September 29, 2010 | work=People.com}}</ref> and became engaged to her in April 2011. They called off the engagement in July 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20512593,00.html | title= Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler Call Off Engagement| author=Jennifer Garcia |date = July 24, 2011| work=People.com}}</ref> but subsequently confirmed their reconciliation that November.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20549737,00.html | title= Kristin Cavallari & Jay Cutler Are Engaged ... Again!| author=Dahvi Shira |date = November 30, 2011| work=People.com}}</ref> Cutler and Cavallari married on June 7, 2013 in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/kristin-cavallari-jay-cutler-married-see-their-wedding-bands-201376|title=Kristin Cavallari, Jay Cutler Married: See Their Wedding Bands!|publisher=''Us Weekly''|date=June 7, 2013 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> They have two sons and one daughter: Camden Jack (born August 8, 2012)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-cutler-cavallari-welcome-baby-boy-20120808,0,7083389.story|title=Cutler, Cavallari welcome baby boy|work=Chicago Tribune|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120808231937/http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-cutler-cavallari-welcome-baby-boy-20120808,0,7083389.story|archivedate=2012-08-08|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/08/08/cutler-cavallari-have-their-baby/ |title=Cutler, Cavallari Have Their Baby « CBS Chicago |publisher=Chicago.cbslocal.com |date=August 8, 2012 |accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref>, Jaxon Wyatt (born May 7, 2014), <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/kristin-cavallari-gives-birth-baby-boy-201475 |title=Kristin Cavallari Gives Birth to a Baby Boy, Welcomes Jaxon Wyatt Cutler With Husband Jay Cutler |work=Us Weekly |date=May 7, 2014 |accessdate=May 8, 2014|first=Rachel|last=McRady}}</ref> and Saylor James (November 23, 2015).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/11/23/jay-cutler-kristin-cavallari-welcome-daughter-saylor-james/|title=Jay Cutler and Kristin Cavallari Welcome Daughter Saylor James|publisher=}}</ref> Despite the birth of his first son coming the day before the Bears played their preseason opener against the [[Denver Broncos]], Cutler dressed for the game, though he did not play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/chicago/nfl/story/_/id/8253238/new-dad-jay-cutler-sits-opener-denver-broncos |title=New dad Jay Cutler sits in opener against Denver Broncos - ESPN Chicago |publisher=Espn.go.com |date=August 10, 2012 |accessdate=August 20, 2012}}</ref>
===Volunteer work=== Cutler does [[volunteer work]] for young people with [[developmental disabilities]] through Vanderbilt's "Best Buddies" program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashville.gov/mc/resolutions/term_2003_2007/rs2006_1124.htm|title=RESOLUTION NO. RS2006-1124|first=Metropolitan Clerk's Office, Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County,|last=Tennessee|website=www.nashville.gov}}</ref>
During the 2007 offseason, Cutler started the Jay Cutler Foundation, which partnered with Mile High United Way’s ''Youth Success Initiative'' to help at-risk youth overcome obstacles and graduate from high school.<ref name=broncossitebio />
On May 1, 2008, Cutler announced that he had been diagnosed with [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|Type 1 diabetes]] and needs daily [[insulin]] shots.<ref>NFL.com, [http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d8081b03e&template=with-video&confirm=true Cutler has Type 1 diabetes, career not in jeopardy]</ref> He is responding well with the insulin treatments.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carucci |first=Vic |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story;jsessionid=2E36B8A73AF760F2FAEF9B26D0AE2647?id=09000d5d8093b349&template=with-video&confirm=true |title=With diabetes under control, Cutler ready to roll |publisher=Nfl.com |date=July 28, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
Cutler works with Dedicated to Diabetes, which is a Denver-based organization that aims to improve public knowledge about diabetes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/may/02/diabetes-education-group-leader-contacts-qb/ |title=Diabetes education group leader contacts QB : Broncos |publisher=The Rocky Mountain News |date=May 2, 2008 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
For the 2009 season, Cutler teamed up with [[Eli Lilly and Company]] in a campaign called "Touchdowns For Diabetes". For every touchdown pass Cutler threw during the 2009 season, Lilly sent a child to diabetes camp by donating $1,000 to the ADA’s “Camp Scholarship” fund—roughly the cost of providing tuition for one child to attend a week of diabetes camp. For every pass Cutler completed in 2009, Lilly donated $100 to the ADA Camp Scholarship fund to allow even more kids the chance to attend camp the following summer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jaycutlersix.com/Touchdowns|title=Touchdowns For Diabetes|publisher=JC6|accessdate=August 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427213206/http://www.jaycutlersix.com/Touchdowns|archivedate=April 27, 2012|df=}}</ref>
In 2012, Cutler visited Perspectives Charter School in Chicago, and talked about diabetes awareness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/NewsStory.asp?story_id=8816 |title=Cutler talks football, diabetes awareness |publisher=Chicagobears.com |date=May 15, 2012 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
===In the media=== An animated representation of Cutler briefly appeared in the ''[[South Park]]'' episode, "[[Guitar Queer-O]]." The show is set in Colorado, and the characters are avid Broncos fans. Two characters, [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] and [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]], meet Cutler and say, "Nice to meet you. I mean, you kinda suck, but my dad says you might be good some day." Cutler himself later responded to the episode, saying, "It was cool. I thought it was funny. They can make fun of me if they want to."<ref>[http://cbs4denver.com/broncos/Denver.Broncos.NFL.2.604965.html cbs4denver.com – Cutler Doesn't Take 'South Park' Insult Personally] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813125606/http://cbs4denver.com/broncos/Denver.Broncos.NFL.2.604965.html |date=August 13, 2009 }}</ref>
Cutler, along with former Broncos tight end [[Tony Scheffler]] and former Broncos backup quarterback [[Preston Parsons]], took part in an episode of ''[[Oprah's Big Give]]'' filmed in Denver in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|author=Bill HustedThe Denver Postdenverpost.com |url=http://www.denverpost.com/husted/ci_8506620 |title=O, hush: Denver edition of "Big Give" a big secret – The Denver Post |publisher=Denverpost.com |date= March 9, 2008|accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/page.php?id=359&contentID=8523 |title=– Official Website Of The Denver Broncos |publisher=Denverbroncos.com |date= |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> The episode aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] on March 9, 2008.
In 2011, after the Bears lost five straight games while Cutler was out with a thumb injury, Chicago recording artist Magic 1 recorded "Cutty Come Back", a parody of the song "[[Baby Come Back (Player song)|Baby Come Back]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2011/12/10/bears-saturday-singalong-cutty-come-back/ |title=NFL.com Blogs " Blog Archive Chicago Saturday sing-along: "Cutty Come Back" " |publisher=Blogs.nfl.com |date=December 10, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref>
An [[internet meme]], called "Smokin' Jay Cutler", portrays pictures of Cutler in an apathetic state with a cigarette photoshopped into his mouth. Cutler commented he is aware of the meme and "gets a kick out of that".<ref>{{cite news |last=Katzowitz |first=Josh |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/20872986/jay-cutler-on-smokin-jay-cutler-i-get-a-kick-out-of-that |title=Jay Cutler on Smokin' Jay Cutler: 'I get a kick out of that' |work=CBS Sports |date=2012-11-07 |accessdate=2015-02-28 }}</ref> [[Aaron Rodgers]] of the [[Green Bay Packers]] performed a smoking gesture to reference the meme during a 38–14 win over the Bears in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |last=Demovsky |first=Rob |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcnorth/post/_/id/67911/aaron-rodgers-smoking-gesture-a-tribute-to-jay-cutler-or-dummy-signal-or-both |title=Aaron Rodgers: Smoking gesture a tribute to Jay Cutler or dummy signal – or both |work=ESPN |date=2014-10-14 |accessdate=2015-02-28 }}</ref>
In 2013 Cutler played himself in an episode of the comedy show ''[[The League]]'', alongside his wife, Kristin Cavallari, who appeared in one other episode of the show.
Cutler supported Presidential Candidate [[Mitt Romney]] in 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/06/chicago-bears-jay-cutler-voting-mitt-romney-_n_2081800.html|title=Chicago Bears' Jay Cutler Voting For Mitt Romney|first=Cavan|last=Sieczkowski|date=6 November 2012|publisher=|via=Huff Post}}</ref> and then-Presidential Candidate [[Donald Trump]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/chicago/bears/post/_/id/4704168/jay-cutler-ive-supported-donald-trump-for-a-while|title=Jay Cutler: I've supported Donald Trump for a while|publisher=}}</ref>

'''John Kelsey''' is a [[cryptographer]] who works at [[NIST]]. His research interests include [[cryptanalysis]] and design of [[symmetric cryptography]] primitives ([[block cipher]]s, [[stream cipher]]s, [[cryptographic hash function]]s, [[Message authentication code|MAC]]s), analysis and design of [[cryptographic protocol]]s, [[CSPRNG|cryptographic random number generation]], [[electronic voting]], [[side-channel attack]]s on cryptography implementations, and anonymizing communications systems. He previously worked at [[Certicom]] and [[Counterpane Internet Security]].
==See also== * [[Yarrow algorithm]], a family of cryptographic [[pseudorandom number generator]]s * [[Twofish]], a [[Symmetric-key algorithm|symmetric key]] [[block cipher]]

'''John Sutherland''' (August 21, 1821 – April 27, 1899) was a [[Manitoba]] political figure. Farmer, Senator.
He was born in [[Point Douglas]] in what was then the [[Red River Colony]] and was educated at [[St. John's College, University of Manitoba|St. John's College]]
Following the flood of 1852, he moved to [[East Kildonan]] where he operated a [[general store]] and farmed.
In 1866 he was appointed to the [[Council of Assiniboia]] which had been created by the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] to govern the territory until it was dissolved in 1870.
During the [[Red River Rebellion]], Sutherland was a leader of the "loyalists" and was a delegate to the [[Council of Forty]] in 1870. In February 1870, the [[Red River Rebellion#Provisional government|Provisional Government of the Red River Colony]] appointed Sutherland Collector of Customs. When Manitoba entered [[Canadian Confederation]] on July 15, 1870, Sutherland was appointed the first [[High Sheriff]] of Manitoba and held the office until December 1871 when he was appointed to the [[Senate of Canada]] by Sir [[John A. Macdonald]] where he sat as an Independent Conservative until his death.
In his later life, Sutherland helped found [[Manitoba College]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox Minister | name = Julián García Vargas | image = Julián García Vargas en la rueda de prensa posterior al Consejo de Ministros.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Julián García Vargas in 1986 | office1=[[Ministry of Health (Spain)|Minister of Health and Consumers]] | primeminister1= Felipe González Márquez | predecessor1= | successor1 = | term_start1 =26 July 1986 | term_end1=March 1991 | office = [[Minister of Defence (Spain)|Minister of Defense]] | primeminister= [[Felipe González Márquez]] | predecessor = | successor= [[Gustavo Suarez]] | term_start=12 March 1991 | term_end=2 July 1995 | birth_date ={{birth year and age|1945}} | birth_place =[[Madrid]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | party = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Universidad Complutense de Madrid]] | spouse = | nationality = [[Spanish people|Spanish]] | religion= | children = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Julián García Vargas''' (born 1945) is a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] economist and socialist politician who served in different cabinets of [[Spain]].
==Early life and education== Garcia was born in [[Madrid]] in 1945.<ref name=mded>{{cite web|title=Julián García Vargas |url=http://www.defensa.gob.es/organizacion/quien/desde/personalidades/quien_65.html |work=Ministerio de Defensa |accessdate=11 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710131326/http://www.defensa.gob.es/organizacion/quien/desde/personalidades/quien_65.html |archivedate=10 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> He received a degree in economic sciences from [[Universidad Complutense de Madrid|the Universidad Complutense de Madrid]] in 1968.<ref name=typsa>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors |url=http://www.typsa.com/eng/01_3_JGV.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630123314/http://www.typsa.com/eng/01_3_JGV.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 June 2013 |work=TYPSA Group |accessdate=1 June 2013 }}</ref>
==Career and activities== Garcia is an economist and healthcare expert by profession.<ref name=esade28feb/> He is a member of [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party|the Socialist Workers' Party]] (PSOE).<ref name=esade28feb>{{cite news|title=The Spanish healthcare system will survive, but it requires urgent changes|url=http://www.esade.edu/web/eng/about-esade/today/news/viewelement/282401/1/former-minister-julian-garcia-vargas,-at-esade:-the-spanish-healthcare-system-will-survive,-but-it-requires-urgent-changes-|accessdate=1 June 2013|work=ESADE|date=28 February 2013}}</ref> He began his career in private sector and then joined public sector where he worked until 1986.<ref name=typsa/>
He was appointed health minister on 26 July 1986 in the cabinet led by the then prime minister [[Felipe Gonzales]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Changes are few as Spain swears in cabinet|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/07/27/world/changes-are-few-as-spain-swears-in-cabinet.html|accessdate=5 September 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=27 July 1986|author=Edward Schumacher}}</ref> Garcia was in office until March 1991.<ref name=typsa/> He is considered to be one of the three Spanish health ministers who significantly improved health-care system of the country.<ref name=mig2012>{{cite book|title=Contemporary Pediatrics|publisher=InTech|isbn=978-953-51-0154-3|url=http://www.aeped.es/sites/default/files/intech-paediatrics_the_people_and_politicians_in_spain_history_development_reality_and_future.pdf|author=Miguel Labay Matías|editor=Öner Özdemir|chapter=Paediatrics, the People and Politicians in Spain – History, Development, Reality and Future|date=3 March 2012}}</ref> He was appointed defense minister on 12 March 1991 in a cabinet reshuffle.<ref name=mded/> He retained his post in the July 1993 reshuffle.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gonzalez brings independents into Spain's cabinet|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/gonzalez-brings-independents-into-spains-cabinet-the-left-wing-is-shut-out-of-new-government-1484781.html|accessdate=4 September 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=14 July 1993|author=Phil Davison|location=Madrid}}</ref> However, Garcia resigned from office on 2 July 1995 due to press reports revealing that [[CESED|the military secret services (CESED)]] had been spying on individuals and public figures.<ref name=mded/><ref name=PDiaz1999>{{cite book|author=Víctor Pérez-Díaz|title=Spain at the Crossroads: Civil Society, Politics and the Rule of Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=56Jr5M85TEcC&pg=PA87|accessdate=1 June 2013|year=1999|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-00052-0|page=87}}</ref> Gustavo Suarez Pertierra succeeded Garcia as defense minister in a cabinet reshuffle.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gonzalez Names New Ministers Following Phone-Tapping Scandal|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1995/Gonzalez-Names-New-Ministers-Following-Phone-Tapping-Scandal/id-3a1a2f77eefb7671f9576fe4dd068647|accessdate=19 October 2013|work=Associated Press|date=30 June 1995}}</ref>
After leaving office he served as the special envoy of [[the European Union]] in [[Mostar]] (Bosnia) from November 1995 to April 1996 for the implementation of [[Dayton Peace Agreement|the Dayton Peace Agreement]].<ref name=typsa/> He was the president of the Spanish Association of Defense Technology, Aeronautics and Space Administration (TEDAE) until his resignation in June 2013.<ref name=efe27jun>{{cite news|title=Julián García Vargas deja de presidir la asociación de empresas de defensa|url=http://www.diariovasco.com/agencias/20130627/economia/julian-garcia-vargas-deja-presidir_201306271825.html|accessdate=9 July 2013|work=diariovasco|date=27 June 2013|agency=EFE|language=Spanish}}</ref> He is the president of the Spanish Atlantic Association.<ref name=incipe>{{cite news|title=European defense and Transatlantic relations |url=http://www.incipe.org/Hispano_Alem_n_Ingl_s.pdf |accessdate=1 June 2013 |work=INCIPE |date=15 December 2005 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He has been board member of several companies.<ref name=typsa/>

{{Infobox person | name = Lilia Cuntapay | image = Lilia Cuntapay.png | caption = | birth_date = September 16, 1935 | birth_place = [[Gonzaga, Cagayan]], Philippines | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|08|20|1935|09|16}} | death_place = [[Pinili, Ilocos Norte]], Philippines | occupation = Actress, Teacher | yearsactive = 1986–2016 | children = 3 | relatives = | homepage = | notable role = | notable_works = ''Shake Rattle & Roll''
''[[Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay]]'' }} '''Lilia Cuntapay''' (September 16, 1935 – August 20, 2016) was a Filipina actress whose debut role was in the Filipino horror film series ''[[Shake, Rattle & Roll (film series)|Shake Rattle and Roll]]'' in 1991. Thereafter, she was dubbed the "Queen of Philippine Horror Movies" due to her roles in many subsequent horror films. She found acclaim for her first leading role, in the film ''[[Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay]]'', which won her an award as Best Actress in the 2011 CinemaOne Originals Digital Film Festival. One of Cuntapay's final TV appearances was in the [[Philippine television drama|teleserye]] ''[[Ang Probinsyano]]''. ==Early life== Cuntapay was born in the Cabiraoan village of [[Gonzaga, Cagayan|Gonzaga]], Cagayan, on September 16, 1935. After she earned her BS degree in Education, she taught in the primary school levels in [[Tuguegarao]]. After Cuntapay stopped teaching, she ventured into the buy-and-sell trade. She also worked in various office staff-level positions in the [[NAPOLCOM|National Police Commission]] (NAPOLCOM). == Career == ===Horror movie extra === Cuntapay was among the 40 actors trained in the first batch of acting workshops conducted by Lori Reyes and [[Peque Gallaga]] for [[LVN Pictures]]. In 1991, Cuntapay played the spooky nanny of [[Kris Aquino]]'s character in ''Shake Rattle & Roll 3'', and in the following year she was cast to play a character identified as an "[[aswang]]" —a role for which she would later be typecast in many subsequent movie appearances, and these earned her the title "Queen of Philippine Horror Movies." After her death a film critic, who assessed the top five performancess of Cuntapay's career, said that in her role for the 1992 film ''Aswang'' : {{quote|Cuntapay was casted as the neighbor thought to be the aswang terrorizing the barrio. This is the start of the flood of horror movie offers.{{cite web|url=https://kami.com.ph/43096-top-5-movie-roles-lilia-cuntapay.html|title=Top 5 movie roles of Lilia Cuntapay|first=Kristin|last=Daniels|publisher=}}}} ===Television appearances=== In 2009, Cuntapay appeared as an [[albularyo]] in the ABS-CBN afternoon TV series ''[[Bud Brothers Series (TV series)|Precious Hearts Romances Presents: Bud Brothers]]''. She was featured in the ''[[Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho]]'' 2009 Halloween Special. She appeared as Rosanna, a role which she shared with [[Maricar Reyes]], in the ''[[Midnight DJ]]'' episode named "Kwentas ng Mangkukulam". Cuntapay was also cast as [[Miley Cyrus]] in ''[[Lokomoko U|Lokomoko High]]'''s spoof of the ''[[Party in the USA]]'' music video. At the end of the year, she had a minor role in the film ''[[Nobody, Nobody But... Juan]]'' — an entry to the [[2009 Metro Manila Film Festival]]. In 2010, Cuntapay played an old lady in ''[[The Last Prince]]'' and a fairy disguised as an old lady in the "Inday Bote" episode of ''[[Wansapanataym]]''. The following year, she played Upeng in the mini-series ''[[Sa Ngalan ng Ina]]'', the first offering of [[Associated Broadcasting Company|TV5]]'s ''TV5 Miniserye'' series in the latter part of 2011. === ''Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay'' and onwards === Cuntapay played a fictionalized version of herself in the [[indie film|indie]] [[mockumentary]] ''[[Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay]]''—described as a bittersweet fictional account on Cuntapay's life as a Philippine showbiz [[Extra (actor)|extra]], an entry to the [[Cinema One|2011 Cinema One Originals]] and directed by Antoinette H. Jadaone. The film won six awards in the 2011 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival, including a Best Actress award for Cuntapay. Cuntapay's last film appearance was ''[[My Bebe Love]]'' in 2015, which was an entry in the 2015 Metro Manila Film Festival.{{cite web|url=http://newscentral.ph/breaking-news/horror-movie-queen-lilia-cuntapay-dies/|title=Horror movie queen Lilia Cuntapay dies|date=20 August 2016|publisher=}} Cuntapay's final TV show appearance was in the action series ''[[Ang Probinsyano]]''. == Personal life == Cuntapay never married but adopted 3 children: Gilmore, Magdalena and Elma. == Death == On August 5, 2016, it was confirmed that Cuntapay suffered from a spinal cord illness and that she was unable to walk. She sought help from her friends and colleagues in the film industry to be able to raise money for her treatment. On August 20, at about 6 a.m, Cuntapay died in her son's home at Barangay Tartarabang in [[Pinili, Ilocos Norte]]; she was 80. ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |-Television ! Liu Aiqin

Liu Xiaoxiao |party = [[Communist Party of China]] }} {{Infobox Chinese |s=刘少奇 |t=劉少奇 |p=Liú Shàoqí |gr=Liou Shawchyi |w=Liu2 Shao4-ch'i2 |mi={{IPAc-cmn|l|you|2|-|sh|ao|4|q|i|2}} |order=st }} '''Liu Shaoqi''' ({{small|pronounced}} {{IPAc-cmn|l|you|2|-|sh|ao|4|q|i|2}}; {{zh|c=刘少奇}}; 24 November 1898{{spaced ndash}}12 November 1969) was a Chinese revolutionary, politician, and theorist. He was [[Chairman of the NPC Standing Committee]] from 1954 to 1959, [[Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China|First Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China]] from 1956 to 1966 and [[President of the People's Republic of China|Chairman (President) of the People's Republic of China]], China's ''de jure'' [[head of state]], from 1959 to 1968, during which he implemented policies of [[economic reconstruction]] in China. For 15 years, President Liu was the third most powerful man in China, behind only Chairman [[Mao Zedong]] and Premier [[Zhou Enlai]]. Originally groomed as Mao's successor, Liu antagonized him in the early 1960s before the [[Cultural Revolution]], and from 1966 onward was criticized, then purged, by Mao. Liu disappeared from public life in 1968 and was labelled the "commander of China's bourgeoisie headquarters", China's foremost "[[capitalist roader|capitalist-roader]]", and a traitor to the revolution. He died under harsh treatment in late 1969, but was [[political rehabilitation|posthumously rehabilitated]] by [[Deng Xiaoping]]'s government in 1980 and granted a national memorial service. ==Biography== ===Youth=== Liu was born into a moderately rich peasant family in Huaminglou village, [[Ningxiang]], [[Hunan]] province;Snow, Edgar, ''Red Star Over China'', Random House (New York), 1938. Citation is from the Grove Press 1973 edition, p.482-484 his ancestral hometown is located at [[Jishui County]], [[Jiangxi]]. He attended Ningxiang Zhusheng Middle School ({{zh|s=宁乡驻省中学|p=Nìngxiāng Zhùshěng zhōngxué}}), and was recommended to attend a class in [[Shanghai]] to prepare for studying in [[Russia]]. In 1920, he and [[Ren Bishi]] joined a Socialist Youth Corps; the next year, Liu was recruited to study at the Comintern's [[University of the Toilers of the East]] in [[Moscow]]. He joined the newly formed [[Communist Party of China]] (CPC) in 1921. The next year he returned to [[China]], and as secretary of the All-China Labor Syndicate led several railway workers' strikes, in the Yangzi Valley and at [[Anyuan District|Anyuan]] on the [[Jiangxi]]-[[Hunan]] border. ===Early political activities=== In 1925, Liu became a member of the [[Guangzhou]]-based All-China Federation of Labor Executive Committee. During the next two years he led numerous political campaigns and strikes in [[Hubei]] and Shanghai. He worked with [[Li Lisan]] in Shanghai in 1925, organizing Communist activity following the [[May Thirtieth Incident]]. After his work in Shanghai, Liu traveled to [[Wuhan]]. He was briefly arrested in [[Changsha]] and then returned to Guangzhou to help organize the 16-month-long [[Canton-Hong Kong strike]].Dittmer, p. 14 He was elected to the Party's [[Central Committee]] in 1927, and was appointed to the head of its Labor Department.Chen, Jerome. ''Mao and the Chinese Revolution,'' (London), 1965, p. 148 Liu returned to work at the Party headquarters in Shanghai in 1929, and was named Secretary of the [[Manchuria|Manchurian]] Party Committee in [[Shenyang|Fengtian]].Dittmer, p. 15 In 1930 and 1931, he attended the Third and Fourth Plenums of the Sixth Central Committee, and was elected to the Central Executive Committee (i.e., Politburo) of the Chinese Soviet Republic in 1931 or 1932. Later in 1932, he left Shanghai and traveled to the [[Jiangxi Soviet]].Snow, p. 482-484 ===Senior leader=== Liu became the Party Secretary of [[Fujian]] Province in 1932. He accompanied the [[Long March]] in 1934 at least as far as the crucial [[Zunyi Conference]], but was then sent to the so-called "White Areas" (areas controlled by the [[Kuomintang]]) to reorganize underground activities in northern China, centered around [[Beijing]] and [[Tianjin]]. He became Party Secretary in North China in 1936, leading the anti-Japanese movements in that area with the assistance of [[Peng Zhen]], [[An Ziwen]], [[Bo Yibo]], [[Ke Qingshi]], [[Liu Lantao]], and [[Yao Yilin]]. Liu ran the Central Plains Bureau in 1939; and, in 1941, the Central China Bureau. Some Japanese sources have alleged that the activities of his organization sparked the [[Marco Polo Bridge Incident]] in July 1937, which gave Japan the excuse to launch the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]].Dittmer 1974, p. 17 citing Tetsuya Kataoka, ''Resistance and Revolution in China: The Communists and the Second United Front'', 1974 pre-publication. In 1937, Liu traveled to the Communist base at [[Yan'an|Yanan]]; in 1941, he became a political commissar of the [[New Fourth Army]]. He was elected as one of five CPC Secretaries at the Seventh National Party Congress in 1945. After that Congress, he became the supreme leader of all Communist forces in Manchuria and northern China, a stature frequently overlooked by historians. Liu became the Vice Chairman of the Central People's Government in 1949. In 1954, China adopted a new constitution at the first [[National People's Congress]] (NPC); at the Congress's first session, he was elected [[Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress|chairman of the Congress's Standing Committee]], a position he held until the second NPC in 1959. From 1956 until his downfall in 1966, he ranked as the First [[Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China]]. Liu's work focused on party organizational and theoretical affairs.Dittmer 1974, p. 206 He was an orthodox Soviet-style Communist, and favored state planning and the development of heavy industry. He elaborated upon his political and economic beliefs in his writings. His best known works include ''How to be a Good Communist'' (1939), ''On the Party'' (1945), and ''Internationalism and Nationalism'' (1952). ===Presidency=== Liu spoke very strongly in favour of the [[Great Leap Forward]] at the Eighth CPC National Congress in May 1958.Dittmer 1974, p. 39–40 At this Congress Liu stood together with [[Deng Xiaoping]] and [[Peng Zhen]] in support of Mao's policies against those who were more critical, such as [[Chen Yun]] and [[Zhou Enlai]]. As a result, Liu gained influence within the party; in April 1959, he succeeded Mao as [[President of the People's Republic of China]]. However, Liu began to voice indications of concern about the outcomes of the Great Leap in the August 1959 [[Lushan Plenum]]. In order to correct the mistakes of the Great Leap Forward, Liu and Deng led economic reforms that bolstered their prestige among the party apparatus and the national populace. Once, he said to Mao: "People write books about cannibalism!" {{cite web|url=http://www.stnn.cc/reveal/200711/t20071116_670118.html |title=刘少奇回应毛泽东：人相食要上书的！_星岛环球网_揭秘 |publisher=Stnn.cc |date=2007-11-16 |accessdate=2012-08-13}} The economic policies of Deng and Liu were notable for being more moderate than Mao's radical ideas. ===Conflict with Mao=== [[File:1939 Liu Shaoqi and Zhou Enlai.jpg|thumb|Liu Shaoqi and [[Zhou Enlai]], 1939]] Liu was publicly acknowledged as Mao's chosen successor in 1961;Dittmer, Lowell, ''Liu Shao-ch’i and the Chinese Cultural Revolution: The Politics of Mass Criticism'', University of California Press (Berkeley), 1974, p. 27 however, by 1962 his opposition to Mao's policies had led Mao to mistrust him. After Mao succeeded in restoring his prestige during the 1960s,Spence, Jonathan D. ''The Search for Modern China'', New York: W.W. Norton and Company. 1999. {{ISBN|0-393-97351-4}} p.566. Liu's eventual downfall became "inevitable". Liu's position as the second-most powerful leader of the CPC contributed to Mao's rivalry with him at least as much as Liu's political beliefs or factional allegiances in the 1960s,Qiu Jin, ''The Culture of Power: the Lin Biao Incident in the Cultural Revolution'', Stanford University Press: Stanford, California. 1999, p.53 indicating that Liu's later persecution was the result of a power struggle that went beyond the goals and well-being of either China or the Party. [[File:Liu Shaoqi and Indira Gandhi.jpg|thumb|Liu Shaoqi and [[Indira Gandhi]], 1954]] [[File:1966-06 1966年刘少奇率团访问巴基斯坦.jpg|thumb|Liu Shaoqi in June 1966, the first year of the Cultural Revolution]] By 1966, few senior leaders in China questioned the need for a widespread reform to combat the growing problems of corruption and bureaucratisation within the Party and the government. With the goal of reforming the government to be more efficient and true to the Communist ideal, Liu himself chaired the enlarged Politburo meeting that officially began the [[Cultural Revolution]]. However, Liu and his political allies quickly lost control of the Cultural Revolution soon after it was called, when Mao used the movement to progressively monopolize political power and to destroy his perceived enemies.Qiu Jin, ''The Culture of Power: the Lin Biao Incident in the Cultural Revolution'', Stanford University Press: Stanford, California. 1999, p.45 Whatever its other causes, the Cultural Revolution, declared in 1966, was overtly pro-Maoist, and gave Mao the power and influence to purge the Party of his political enemies at the highest levels of government. Along with closing China's schools and universities, and Mao's exhortations to young Chinese to randomly destroy old buildings, temples, and art, and to attack their teachers, school administrators, party leaders, and parents,Spence, Jonathan D. ''The Search for Modern China'', New York: W.W. Norton and Company. 1999. {{ISBN|0-393-97351-4}} p.575. the Cultural Revolution also increased Mao's prestige so much that entire villages adopted the practice of offering prayers to Mao before every meal.Spence, Jonathan D. ''The Search for Modern China'', New York: W.W. Norton and Company. 1999. {{ISBN|0-393-97351-4}} p.584 In both national politics and Chinese popular culture, Mao established himself as a demigod accountable to no one, purging any that he suspected of opposing himBarnouin, Barbara and Yu Changgen. Zhou Enlai: A Political Life. Hong Kong: Chinese University of Hong Kong, 2006. {{ISBN|962-996-280-2}} p.4 and directing the masses and [[Red Guards]] "to destroy virtually all state and party institutions". After the Cultural Revolution was announced, most of the most senior members of the CPC who had voiced any hesitation in following Mao's direction, including Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping, were removed from their posts almost immediately; and, with their families, subjected to mass criticism and humiliation. Liu and Deng, along with many others, were denounced as "[[capitalist roader]]s". Liu was labeled as a "traitor" and "the biggest capitalist roader in the Party"; he was displaced as [[Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China|Party Deputy Chairman]] by [[Lin Biao]] in July 1966. By 1967, Liu and his wife [[Wang Guangmei]] were placed under house arrest in Beijing. Liu was removed from all his positions and expelled from the Party in October 1968. After his arrest, Liu disappeared from public view. ===Vilification, death and rehabilitation=== Liu was beaten regularly at public denunciation meetings after his arrest in 1967. He was denied medicine for his diabetes, by then a long-term illness, and for pneumonia, which he developed after his arrest. Liu was eventually given treatment only when [[Jiang Qing]] feared he would die; she desired that Liu be kept alive to serve as a "living target" during the [[9th National Congress of the Communist Party of China|Ninth Party Congress]] in 1969.Chung, Jang. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TYHPLULRAtAC&pg=PA391&lpg=PA391&dq=peng+dehuai+head+tumor&source=bl&ots=sWKyWnDcbw&sig=-usZwF_AREYvmJxp7Kw7K1UAf9o&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hUa5T-2JC8qkiQKJs7XxBg&ved=0CG4Q6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=peng%20dehuai%20head%20tumor&f=false ''White Swans: Three Daughters of China'']. Touchstone: New York, NY. 2003. p.391. {{ISBN|0-7432-4698-5}}. At the Congress, Liu was denounced as a traitor and an enemy agent. Zhou Enlai read the Party verdict that Liu was "a criminal traitor, enemy agent and scab in the service of the imperialists, modern revisionists and the Kuomintang reactionaries". Liu's conditions did not improve after he was denounced in the Congress, and he died soon afterward.{{cite book |title=Humanity : A Moral History of the Twentieth Century |last=Glover |first=Jonathan |publisher=London: J. Cape |year=1999 |page=289 |isbn=0-300-08700-4 |authorlink=Jonathan Glover}} In a memoir written by Liu's principal physician, he disputed the alleged medical maltreatment of Liu during his last days. According to Dr. Gu Qihua, there was a dedicated medical team in charge of treating Liu's illness; between July 1968 and October 1969, Liu had seven total occurrences of pneumonia due to his deteriorating immune system, and there had been a total of 40 group consultations by top medical professionals regarding the treatment of this disease. Liu was closely monitored daily by the medical team, and they made the best effort given the adverse circumstance. He died of illness on November 12, 1969, and was cremated next day.[http://history.sina.com.cn/bk/wgs/2013-11-12/155073840_2.shtml Liu Shaoqi's Emergency Treatment] 回忆抢救刘少奇, 炎黄春秋 (Nov. 2009) In February 1980, two years after [[Deng Xiaoping]] came to power, the Fifth Plenum of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued the "Resolution on the Rehabilitation of Comrade Liu Shaoqi". The resolution declared Liu's ouster to be unjust and removed the labels of "renegade, traitor and scab" that had been attached to him at the time of his death. It also declared him to be "a great Marxist and proletarian revolutionary" and recognized him as one of the principal leaders of the Party. Lin Biao was blamed for "concocting false evidence" against Liu, and for working with the [[Gang of Four]] to subject him to "political frame-up and physical persecution". A high-profile national memorial ceremony was held for Liu on May 17, 1980, and his ashes were scattered into the sea at Qingdao in accordance with his last wishes.{{cite web| url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/CPC_90_anniversary/2011-06/22/content_22838789.htm|title= Rehabilitation of Liu Shaoqi (Feb. 1980)| accessdate= November 22, 2011}}[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/344491/Liu-Shaoqi/ Liu Shaoqi] at [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] ==Personal life== Liu married five times, including He Baozhen (何宝珍){{cite web|url=http://www.wangjiwang.com/Memorial/memorial_shc.aspx?id=3791|title=The wives of Liu Xioaqi (刘少奇婚姻家庭)|language=Chinese|accessdate=January 29, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317181130/http://www.wangjiwang.com/Memorial/memorial_shc.aspx?id=3791|archive-date=March 17, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} and [[Wang Guangmei]] (王光美).{{cite web|url=http://vip.book.sina.com.cn/book/index_41074.html|title=Interview with former Chairman Liu Xiaoqi’s wife He Baozhen (前国家主席刘少奇夫人王光美访谈录)|language=Chinese|publisher=[[Sina.com]]|accessdate=January 29, 2011}} His third wife Xie Fei (谢飞) came from [[Wenchang]], Hainan and was one of the few women on the 1934 [[Long March]].{{cite web|url= http://hi.people.com.cn/2006/10/23/269193.html|title=Extraordinary wife of Liu Xiaoqi at the time of the Long March (长征时与刘少奇结伉俪，琼籍女红军传奇人生)|language=Chinese|accessdate=January 29, 2011}} His wife at the time of his death in 1969, Wang Guangmei, was thrown into prison by Mao Zedong during the Cultural Revolution; she was subjected to harsh conditions in solitary confinement for more than a decade.{{Cite book| author= Lieberthal, Kenneth|title=Governing China: From Revolution to Reform|publisher= w.w.Norton, New York 1995}} ==See also== {{Portal|China|Biography}} * [[History of the People's Republic of China]] * [[Liu Shaoqi's Former Residence]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist}} === Sources === {{refbegin}} * "Fifth Plenary Session of 11th C.C.P. Central Committee", ''Beijing Review'', No. 10 (10 March 1980), pp. 3–10, which describes the official rehabilitation measures. {{refend}} ==External links== * [http://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/liu-shaoqi/index.htm The Liu Shaoqi Reference Archive] {{-}} {{s-start}} {{s-par}} {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress]]|years=1954–1959}} {{s-aft|after=[[Zhu De]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mao Zedong]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[President of the People's Republic of China]]|years=1959–1968}} {{s-aft|after=''[[Dong Biwu]] and [[Soong Ching-ling]] (acting)''}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mao Zedong]]}} {{s-ttl|title=President of the [[Communist Party of China|CPC]] [[Central Party School]]|years=1947–1953}} {{s-aft|after=[[Kai Feng (politician)|Kai Feng]]}} |- {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
'''Lois K. Alexander-Lane''' (born '''Lois Marie Kindle'''; 11 June 1916<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/26/AR2007102602221.html|title=Lois Alexander Lane; Founder Of Harlem Institute of Fashion|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|date=2007-10-27|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-29}}</ref> - 29 September 2007) was an African American fashion designer and founded the [[Black Fashion Museum]] in 1979.
== Personal life == Alexander-Lane was born in Little Rock, Arkansas.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/21/AR2010052101654_3.html?sid=ST2010052101774|title=Black Fashion Museum collection finds a fine home with Smithsonian|date=2010-05-23|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
Alexander-Lane received her master's degree at [[New York University]] in 1963, she proposed a thesis on the historic role of African Americans in Manhattan retailing; her professor responded by saying African Americans played no such role. Her resulting thesis—and later her life's work—proved otherwise.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmaahc.si.edu/Collections/BlackFashion|title=Black Fashion Museum Collection Collections {{!}} National Museum of African American History and Culture|website=nmaahc.si.edu|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
== Career == The Black Fashion Museum first opened in 1979 in Harlem, originally established in Harlem on West 126th Street that now houses the [[Clinton Foundation|William J. Clinton Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/21/AR2010052101654_3.html?sid=ST2010052101774|title=Black Fashion Museum collection finds a fine home with Smithsonian|date=2010-05-23|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> The museum relocated to Washington, D.C. in 1994 to a historic row house at 2007 Vermont Ave. NW.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/21/AR2010052101654.html?sid=ST2010052101774|title=Black Fashion Museum collection finds a fine home with Smithsonian|last=Givhan|first=Robin|date=2010-05-23|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
== Death and legacy == Alexander-Lane eventually published her own book, Blacks in the History of Fashion in 1982. Alexander-Lane died in 2007 at the age of 91. The Black Fashion Museum collection was donated to the [[National Museum of African American History and Culture|Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture]] in 2007 by her daughter Joyce Bailey.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/21/AR2010052101654.html?sid=ST2010052101774|title=Black Fashion Museum collection finds a fine home with Smithsonian|last=Givhan|first=Robin|date=2010-05-23|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
"The Black Fashion Museum collection was originally stored in a two-story row house on Vermont Avenue in Washington, D.C. The collection comprises more than 700 garments, 300 accessories, and 60 boxes of archival material collected by Alexander-Lane throughout her life. The research collection—one of the largest and rarest of its kind—includes a dress sewn by Rosa Parks shortly before her famous arrest in Montgomery, Ala.; a beige-patterned skirt worn by an enslaved child in Leesburg, Va.; the original Tin Man costume designed by Geoffrey Holder for the 1975 Broadway musical, The Wiz."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmaahc.si.edu/Collections/BlackFashion|title=Black Fashion Museum Collection Collections {{!}} National Museum of African American History and Culture|website=nmaahc.si.edu|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
"Clothing and bonnets worn by slaves in the mid-1800s appear alongside an elaborately constructed opera cape made by a former slave. Other items include gowns by [[Ann Lowe]], a pioneering African American designer whose patrons included the Rockefellers, the Du Ponts, the Vanderbilts, and Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy. 'The objects not only tell the story of black fashion,' Moresi says, 'but of the women and men who created them, wore them and held on to them for years.' "<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmaahc.si.edu/Collections/BlackFashion|title=Black Fashion Museum Collection Collections {{!}} National Museum of African American History and Culture|website=nmaahc.si.edu|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
